ARTICLE II. - MAYOR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Mayor, § 15. 
State Law reference- Qualifications of mayors, W. Va. Code § 8-5-7; powers and duties of mayors generally, W. Va. Code § 8-10-1; mayor presiding officer at council meetings, W. Va. Code § 8-9-1; right of mayor to vote in council meetings, W. Va. Code § 8-9-2. 

Sec. 2-31. - Function. 
    The mayor shall be the head of the city government and the chief executive officer of the city. It shall be his duty to see that all of the laws and ordinances of the city are enforced; and he shall have general supervision over all executive departments, offices and agencies of the city government. 
(Code 1975, § 2-30) 
Secs. 2-32-2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY COUNCIL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Proceedings of municipal governing bodies, W. Va. Code § 8-9-1 et seq.; ordinances and ordinance procedures, W. Va. Code § 8-11-1 et seq.; general powers of city, powers, duties and allied relations, W. Va. Code § 8-12-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-61. - Regular and special meetings. 
    The city council shall meet in regular public session on the first and third Mondays of each month, at such hour and at such place as shall be specified in the rules of the council, as provided in section 21 of the city's Charter. Special meetings may be called as provided in section 22 of the city's Charter. 
(Code 1975, § 2-14) 
Charter reference- Regular council meetings, § 21; special meetings, § 22. 
Sec. 2-62. - Same-Annual tax estimate and levy. 
    Prior to the first day of March in each year the mayor shall fix a date and time between the seventh and 28th days of March, and at a time and on the date so fixed the council shall meet in public session at the council chamber in the city building and shall then and there proceed with the transaction of the business which is the subject of W. Va. Code § 11-8-14. Upon completion of that business, the session shall stand adjourned until a time so fixed by the mayor on the next following third Tuesday in April, at which time it shall reconvene and the council shall proceed in conformity with the provisions of W. Va. § 11-8-14a. 
(Code 1975, § 2-15; Bill. No. 6899, § 2-15, 4-15-2002) 
Charter reference- Annual estimate of receipts and expenditures, Char., § 50. 
State Law reference- Meetings for purpose of tax levies, W. Va. Code § 11-8-9; requirement that city clerk forward a fiscal statement to state tax commission, and publish a copy thereof, immediately following the council meeting in March, W. Va. Code § 11-8-14. 
Sec. 2-63. - Quadrennial organizational. 
(a)  At 10:00 a.m. on the third Monday of June in the year 1999, and every four years thereafter, the mayor-elect and councilmen-elect shall meet in special public session at the council chamber in the city building, and shall be called to order by the incumbent city clerk or, in her absence, a deputy or assistant city clerk; and the mayor-elect and councilmen-elect shall then proceed to take the prescribed oath of office, whereupon they shall be deemed to have qualified themselves for the offices to which they, respectively, have recently been elected; provided, that the mayor-elect shall not be deemed to have qualified until he shall have given bond as provided in section 25 of the city Charter. 
(b)  The city council shall then elect a president pro tempore of the council from among the councilmembers, and may then proceed with other business of an organizational nature such as adopting, amending or readopting rules not inconsistent with this Code; filling vacancies in offices for which the appointing authority is the council or the mayor with the approval of the council; the appointment of members of council committees; and other matters relating to the organization of the city government generally for the ensuing four-year period. 
(Code 1975, § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-64. - Clerk of the council. 
(a)  The city clerk, in his ex officio capacity as clerk of the council, shall render such secretarial and clerical services for the city council, its committees, its members and presiding officer, as may be imposed upon him by the city's Charter and general laws of the state, this Code, and other ordinances, resolutions and orders of the council; and he shall be the custodian of all records and papers of the council. 
(b)  The clerk of the council shall prepare summary copies of the minutes of each meeting of the city council and shall transmit by mail one copy to each member of the council and a copy to the mayor within ten days after the meeting is adjourned. 
(Code 1975, § 2-17) 
Charter reference- Clerk to be clerk of council, § 28. 
State Law reference- Keeping of records of all council proceedings, ordinances, etc., W. Va. Code § 8-9-3. 
Sec. 2-65. - Authentication of records. 
    All records of the city council shall be authenticated by the signature of the mayor and attested by the signature of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-66. - Sergeant at arms. 
(a)  The chief of police shall attend all meetings of the city council in the capacity of sergeant at arms; he shall, under directions of the presiding officer, aid in the enforcement of good order and decorum and execute all such process as shall issue under authority of the council. 
(b)  At the request of the presiding officer of any committee or subcommittee of the city council, the chief of police shall designate a police officer to attend meetings of such committee or subcommittee in the capacity of assistant sergeant at arms, who shall, under directions of the presiding officer, aid in the enforcement of good order and decorum, and execute all such process as shall issue under authority of the council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-19) 
Sec. 2-67. - Authorized procedure when meeting lacks quorum. 
    Any number of members of the city council, less than a quorum, which may meet at the time and place appointed for any regular or special meeting of the council, may direct the sergeant at arms and his deputies to compel the attendance of the absent members, or they may adjourn to a subsequent time and direct the sergeant at arms to give notice to the absent members, requiring their attendance at such adjourned meeting. 
(Code 1975, § 2-20) 
Charter reference- Authority of less than a quorum of council to compel attendance of absentees, § 26. 
Sec. 2-68. - Disorderly conduct prohibited at meetings of council and council committees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to behave in a boisterous or disorderly manner at any meeting of the city council or any committee of the council, or to cause any disturbance at such meeting, whether by force, shouting or other action tending to disrupt such meeting, or to fail or refuse to obey any ruling or order of the officer presiding at such meeting relative to the orderly procedure of such meeting. 
(b)  Boisterous or disorderly behavior within the purview of subsection (a) of this section shall include but is not limited to any of the following acts: 
(1)  Contemptuous or insolent behavior towards the presiding officer or any member of the city council or committee of the council, or its clerk, sergeant at arms or any other officer, while the council or committee is in session. 
(2)  Any breach of the peace, willful disturbance, or indecent conduct in the presence of such council or committee while so engaged, or so near as to obstruct or interrupt its proceedings. 
(3)  Violence or threats of violence to any member of such council or committee or any officer, witness or party going to, attending or returning from any council or committee proceeding in respect to anything done or to be done in the course of such proceeding. 
(4)  Willful resistance to any lawful order of the presiding officer or sergeant at arms at any such meeting. 
(c)  The presiding officer of the city council or of any committee of the city council shall have plenary power to order that the council chamber or any part of the chamber and adjacent areas be cleared or any person ejected from the council chamber or adjacent areas in the event of disorderly conduct or disturbance which does or tends to interrupt or disrupt the orderly conduct of business by the council or its committee. 
(Code 1975, § 2-21) 
Sec. 2-69. - Resolutions and record. 
(a)  Each resolution shall, before its introduction, be reduced to writing and shall be signed by the person who introduces it; and the clerk of the council shall then number it and, when adopted, shall spread it in full upon the minutes of the city council. The clerk of the council shall then place the original copy of such resolution in his office in a file to be known as the record of resolutions. 
(b)  Resolutions and portions of resolutions which are repealed or amended by subsequent resolutions or ordinances shall be noted and initialed in the margin by the clerk of the council, so as to show the date and number of the repealing or amendatory ordinance or resolution, but shall not be removed from the record of resolutions. 
(Code 1975, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-70. - Adoption of rules of the council; amending, repealing, filing and publication of rules; maintenance of rules in current status. 
(a)  The city council may, by resolution as well as by ordinance, make proper rules and regulations for its own government and for the conduct of its meetings, the transaction of its business and the official conduct of its members, and may include in such rules and regulations reasonable penalties for violation; but no such rule shall be inconsistent with the state law, the Charter or this Code. Such rules may include, among other subjects, the following: 
(1)  Appointment, jurisdiction and duties of standing and special committees of the council. 
(2)  Attendance at meetings of the council by members and by others. 
(3)  Investigations and hearings, and compulsory attendance at such investigations and hearings of witnesses and the production of books and papers. 
(4)  Parliamentary procedure. 
(5)  Preservation of order at meetings. 
(6)  Manner and form of petitions, applications and other papers intended for presentation to the council, and related procedures. 
(b)  Each of the rules of the city council as set out in the appendix to this article on the effective date of this Code shall be effective as and have the status of a resolution of the council on the effective date of this Code, and all other rules of the council theretofore in effect and whether having been established by resolution or ordinance shall then stand repealed and have no force or effect whatever. 
(c)  All rules adopted pursuant to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section on or after the effective date of this Code shall be spread upon the minutes of the city council and duly entered of record in the office of the clerk of the council and shall be published in this Code in the appendix to this article. As such rules may from time to time be repealed, amended or added to, the file copies of this Code and the record of repealed and amended portions shall be brought up to date and maintained in a current status in the same manner as provided for ordinances in subsections 2-94(b), (c) and (e). 
(Code 1975, § 2-27) 
Charter reference- Council rules, § 20. 
Secs. 2-71-2-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ORDINANCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Ordinances, § 41. 
State Law reference- Ordinances, W. Va. Code § 8-11-4. 

Sec. 2-91. - General provisions as to adoption and procedures. 
    No ordinance shall be passed except by bill and in accordance with the requirements of W. Va. Code § 8-11-4, except where different or additional requirements are specified in other sections of the W. Va. Code, in which event such other different or additional requirements shall be applicable. 
(Code 1975, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-92. - Cases requiring enactment of ordinance. 
(a)  In the following enumerated cases, the action of the city council shall, except where otherwise provided in W. Va. Code, be by ordinance: 
(1)  Levying taxes or providing for the collection of fees of any kind. 
(2)  Requiring a license to do business. 
(3)  Relating to offenses and penalties. 
(4)  Authorizing the issuance of bonds or other forms of indebtedness. 
(5)  Providing for a public improvement. 
(6)  Providing for the purchase of private property by the city or for the sale of property belonging to the city. 
(7)  Laying out or vacating a public street, avenue, road, alley or way. 
(8)  Relating to planning or zoning. 
(9)  Granting franchises to public utilities. 
(10)  Providing for a contractual or other agreement with another jurisdiction. 
(11)  Relating to such other matters as the Charter may require. 
(b)  The action of the city council shall also be by ordinance in any other case in which an ordinance is required by the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 2-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 8-11-3. 
Sec. 2-93. - Recording and filing; ordinance record book. 
    Each ordinance when adopted shall be spread in full upon the council records and entered in the ordinance record book as required by section 42 of the city's Charter, and the original copy of the ordinance shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-24) 
State Law reference- Record of proceedings, ordinances, resolutions, etc., required, W. Va. Code § 8-9-3. 
Sec. 2-94. - To repeal, amend or add to provisions of this Code, and record; record of repealed and amended portions of Code. 
(a)  Each bill which proposes an ordinance to repeal, amend or add to any portion of this Code and each bill which proposes an ordinance of a general and permanent nature, though constituting new subject matter, shall be drafted so as to specify the specific section numbers, subsections, etc., of this Code which are to be repealed or amended and, with respect to additions and to new subject matter, so as to provide appropriate chapter, article, section, etc., numbers; and each amendment of and addition to this Code shall be set out in full, and appropriate chapter and article headings and section catchlines shall be included. 
(b)  Upon the adoption of an ordinance to repeal, amend or add to any portion of this Code, or to include new subject matter in this Code, the clerk of the council shall separate the several chapters, articles, sections, etc., of such ordinance and enter them in their proper places in each file copy of this Code and shall delete from this Code any portion so repealed or amended; and in the margin of each insertion in the file copies of this Code, he shall note and initial the date of passage, effective date and number of the amending or repealing ordinance and, if publication is required, a note as to the time and manner of publication. 
(c)  Items removed from the file copies of this Code pursuant to subsection (b) of this section shall be maintained by the clerk of the council in a separate looseleaf volume, arranged properly according to their respective chapters, articles, sections, etc.; and each item so removed from the file copies of this Code shall, in the margin of each such item, be noted and initialed by him to show the effective date and the number of both the enacting and repealing or amending ordinances. The volume in which such repealed and amended items are to be included shall be known as the "Record of Repealed and Amended Portions of the Code of the City of Charleston, West Virginia," the purpose of which is to enable city officers and other persons interested to ascertain the status of this Code at any given time in the past; and it shall also be the duty of the clerk of the council to maintain on file in his office at least one copy of each prior codification or compilation of the city and town ordinances, insofar as copies may be available to him for such purpose. 
(d)  The requirements of subsection (b) of this section are in addition to the requirement that each ordinance, upon adoption, shall be included in the ordinance record book. 
(e)  The term "file copies" as used in this section shall mean that copy or those copies, as the case may be, of this Code, certified by the mayor upon adoption, and thereafter maintained on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-25) 
Secs. 2-95-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Elected officers, § 4. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-17(8); housing commissioner, § 14-92; assistants and employees of housing commissioner, § 14-93; director and department personnel of consumer protection department, § 34-34; deputy clerk of municipal court, § 38-35; chief of the fire department, § 54-43; chief of police, § 66-31; school crossing guards, § 66-91 et seq.; director and other personnel of parks and recreation department, § 82-42; chairman and secretary of parks and recreation commission, § 82-83; personnel director, § 86-52; chairman and secretary of municipal planning commission, § 90-36; city manager ex officio sanitation inspector, § 98-43; director of refuse collection, § 98-44; officers of sanitary board, § 118-122. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-131. - Duties of officers and employees. 
    The city council shall prescribe the duties of all of the officers and employees of the city where not prescribed by the city's Charter, and it shall be the duty of all such officers and employees to perform faithfully and diligently all the duties so prescribed by the council, and the failure so to do by any officer or employee of the city shall be deemed neglect of duty and good cause for dismissal. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city council to prescribe the powers and duties of city officers and employees, W. Va. Code § 8-5-11. 
Sec. 2-132. - Authority of deputies, assistants and other subordinates. 
    Authority vested in and duties imposed upon city officers by state law, the city's Charter, this Code or other ordinances and resolutions of the city council may, when they so authorize, be exercised or performed by their deputies, assistants and other subordinates, to the extent not prohibited by state law, the city's Charter, this Code or other ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-133. - Faithful performance and true accounting bonds required of all officers and of certain agents and employees of city. 
(a)  Every officer of the city, whether or not required by the Charter or by any other ordinance of the city or by any order of the city council, and in addition to every city officer, every employee or agent of the city who in the course of his official duties collects, receives, handles or has custody or control of city funds, negotiable instruments or securities of value in excess of $100.00 at any one time, or who collects coins from parking meters regardless of the amount, shall, before entering upon the duties of his office or position and within two weeks after his election or appointment, give bond, with corporate surety, payable to the city, in such amount not less than $1,000.00 as shall be determined from time to time by the city council, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, a true accounting to give of all city funds, negotiable instruments and securities collected, received or handled by him or coming within his custody or control, and payment to the city; provided, that the bonds of the mayor, health commissioner, chief of police and chief of the fire department, respectively, be in an amount not less than $1,000.00; the bond of the city treasurer be in an amount not less than $60,000.00; the bonds of the city manager and city collector, respectively, be in an amount not less than $10,000.00; and the bonds of the city clerk, municipal court clerk, municipal court judge and city solicitor, respectively, be in an amount not less than $3,000.00; and provided further, that the bonds of deputies and assistants be in amounts not less than the bonds of their respective principals; and provided further, that during any period when two or more offices or positions are held by the same person, the bond for such person shall be in an amount not less than the highest amount required for any one of such offices or positions. 
(b)  The city council may adopt a system of blanket faithful performance and honesty building as an alternative to the individual bonds provided in subsection (a) of this section; provided, that the minimum amounts specified in subsection (a) for the offices and positions named shall remain the same as specified. 
(c)  The city solicitor shall approve all bonds required by this section as to their form and legality; and, unless otherwise provided at any time by the city council, the city clerk shall approve all such bonds, except his own, as to sufficiency, and the mayor shall approve the city clerk's bond as to sufficiency. 
(d)  The premiums on all such bonds shall be paid by the city. 
(e)  All bonds required by this section shall be in the custody of the city clerk, except that the bond of the city clerk shall be in the custody of the mayor. 
(Code 1975, § 2-2) 
Charter reference- Bonds, § 25. 
State Law reference- Authority to require bonds of city officers and employees, W. Va. Code § 8-12-5(46), (47); official bonds of public officers, W. Va. Code § 6-2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-134. - Bond required of those authorized to carry firearms. 
(a)  Each officer, employee and agent of the city who in the course of his official duties is authorized to carry any firearm shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, give bond to the city, with corporate surety and in such amount as may be fixed by the city council but not less than $3,500.00, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties and for the payment of all damages, judgments and decrees resulting from the negligent or unlawful use of such firearm by himself or by any other person with his knowledge and consent. 
(b)  The city solicitor shall approve all bonds required by this section with respect to their form and legality, and the premiums shall be paid by the city. The city clerk shall approve all bonds required by this section with respect to their sufficiency unless otherwise provided at any time by the city council. 
(c)  All bonds required by this section shall be in the custody of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-135. - Persons acting in place of those who are absent or disabled or when position is vacant. 
    When any city officer or employee is absent or disabled or when any office or position in the city government is vacant, the person designated by competent authority to act in the place of such absent or disabled city officer or employee or to hold temporarily the vacant office or position shall have the powers and perform the duties of such absent or disabled officer or employee or appertaining to such vacant office or position. 
(Code 1975, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-136. - Conflicts of interest. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any elective or appointive officer or employee of the city to be interested personally, either directly or indirectly or as a member, manager, officer or stockholder of any partnership, business, firm or corporation, in any contract furnishing material, services or supplies to the city or to any contractor or workers for the city, or in any manner whatsoever, whereby the taxpayers of the city shall become the paymaster, either directly or indirectly. Any violation of this subsection shall be a misdemeanor; and upon conviction, such officer or employee shall be deemed to have vacated his office or position; and he shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not be applicable to members of boards of commissions who receive no compensation from the city for their services as such members. 
(c)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not be applicable to members of the council. No member of the council shall vote on any question before the city council if he is directly and immediately interested in the question. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6; Ord. No. 4925, 9-20-1993) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, W. Va. Code § 8-5-19. 
Sec. 2-137. - Ethics in city government. 
(a)  The council finds that the financial disclosure provisions of the West Virginia Governmental Ethics Act (W. Va. Code § 6B-1-1 et seq.) have reasonable, necessary and appropriate application to matters involving all elected municipal officials, whether full- or part-time, who derive a salary, payment of wages or other direct remuneration of the city, and does affirm, ratify and adopt the state defined purposes as being the same purposes of this section without specifically republishing the state purposes in this section. 
(b)  The council further finds that for the purpose of assisting in the administration of the provisions of this section, the financial disclosure provisions as set forth in W. Va. Code §§ 6B-2-6, 6B-2-7 and 6B-2-8 shall be expressly adopted and incorporated as provisions of this section. 
(c)  Any amendment to any of the statutory provisions of the state which are expressly adopted in and incorporated as provisions of this section shall upon enactment by the state legislature, pursuant to the state prescribed effective date, be deemed to be an amendment to this section unless the city expressly opts not to adopt any such amendment by ordinance duly adopted by the council evidencing the nonadoption of such amendments. 
(Ord. No. 4467, 2-4-1991) 
State Law reference- Public ethics, W. Va. Code § 6B-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-138. - Standards of conduct of city employees for federal grants; penalties. 
(a)  No municipal officer or employee for the city shall accept or receive directly or indirectly from any person known by such officer or employee to be interested in any bid, contract or purchase, by rebate, gift or otherwise, any money or other thing of value whatsoever or any promise, obligation or contract for future reward or compensation when such contract is to be funded in whole or in part by any federal grant funds. Any contract or purchase funded solely by nonfederal funds shall be governed by the provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 61, art. 5A (W. Va. Code § 61-5A-1 et seq.) relating to bribery and corrupt practices. 
(b)  Any person violating subsection (a) of this section relating to federal funds shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or by both fine and imprisonment. In addition to the criminal penalty, such officer or employee shall be subject to such disciplinary action as may be appropriate; and any such contract or purchase entered into shall be null and void. 
(Code 1975, § 2-84.1) 
State Law reference- Authorized penalty for ordinance violations, W. Va. Code §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-5(57), 8-34-1. 
Sec. 2-139. - Right of entry for purposes of inspection. 
    Whenever any officer or employee of the city is required or authorized by statute, the provisions of this Code or any ordinance, resolution, or pertinent rules and regulations or orders, in order to carry out his duties, to enter any premises or vehicle for the purpose of making an inspection or of anything contained in such premises or vehicle, such officer or employee shall have the right to enter any such premises or vehicle in accordance with law at any reasonable time and upon display of proper identification in pursuance of such duties. This section shall not be construed as purporting to authorize an unreasonable search and seizure prohibited by section 3-6 of the Constitution of West Virginia. 
(Code 1975, § 2-7) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to provide for the entering and inspection of private premises, W. Va. Code § 8-12-15. 
Sec. 2-140. - Limited authority to administer oaths; false swearing. 
(a)  The mayor, the presiding officer of the city council for the time being, the presiding officer of any city council committee or of any board, com 
mission or other body of the city government, and each city officer, his deputies and assistants, to whom any sworn report, return, certificate, pledge or statement, whether oral or in writing, is required to be made or submitted by any person pursuant to any provision of this Code or other ordinance or resolution of the city council, shall have authority to administer any required oath; however, nothing in this section shall be construed as purporting to authorize the administration of any oath which, by law, is required to be administered by a judicial officer, notary public or other officer authorized by statute to administer oaths; nor shall this section be construed as purporting to authorize the taking of any acknowledgement of any signature or seal for the purpose of recording in the office of the clerk of the county court or elsewhere other than in the office of the city clerk or some other officer of this city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to whom an oath has been administered pursuant to this section to knowingly make any false report, return, certificate or statement, oral or written, concerning any matter whatsoever in violation of such oath. 
(Code 1975, § 2-28) 
State Law reference- False swearing, W. Va. Code § 61-5-2. 
Secs. 2-141-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BENEFITS 

Sec. 2-161. - Compensation of city officers and employees. 
(a)  Officers and employees of the city shall receive as compensation for their services such salaries, wages and other emoluments as may be provided in the annual budget or other action, order, resolution or ordinance of the city council. Fees paid to the city officers and employees for documents or services rendered in the performance of official duty shall be paid over by them to the city and shall not be deemed to constitute compensation to them personally. 
(b)  Commencing with the third Monday in June 2007, the mayor of the city shall receive as compensation for his services the sum of $100,000.00 per annum; the judge of the municipal court of the city shall receive the sum of $35,000.00 per annum; the treasurer of the city shall receive the sum of $18,000.00 per annum; and each member of the city council shall receive the sum of $115.00 per meeting, with a maximum yearly compensation of $3,450.00, with payments conditioned upon the councilmember's being present; and commencing with the third Monday in June 2011, each member of the city council shall receive the sum of $200.00 per meeting, with a maximum yearly compensation of $5,600.00, with payments conditioned upon the councilmember's being present. Notwithstanding the compensation set forth in this subsection (b) for the mayor, the judge of the municipal court, and each member of city council, beginning on the first Monday in January 2019, the compensation for the mayor, the judge of the municipal court, and each member of city council shall increase as set forth in subsection (c) herein. 
(c)  Commencing with the first Monday in January 2019, the mayor of the city shall receive as compensation for services the sum of $125,000.00 per annum; and the judge of the municipal court shall receive as compensation for services the sum of $40,000.00 per annum; and each member of the city council shall receive the sum of $250.00 per City Council meeting attended, with a maximum yearly compensation of $7,000.00 per member. 
(Code 1975, § 27-4; Ord. No. 4631, 10-13-1990; Ord. No. 6470, 7-6-1998; Bill No. 7263, 6-4-2007; Bill No. 7733, 3-16-17; Bill No. 7734, 3-16-17; Bill No. 7735, 3-16-17) 
State Law reference- Authority to fix compensation of officers and employees, W. Va. Code § 8-5-12. 
Sec. 2-162. - Federal social security. 
    The city council, having heretofore elected to extend the benefits of title II of the federal Social Security Act to all eligible city officers and employees, as provided in W. Va. Code § 5-7-5, declares that the plan for extending those benefits as heretofore submitted to and approved by the state auditor in his capacity as the state agency shall continue in full force and effect and that the city shall conform to all applicable provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 5, art. 7 (W. Va. Code § 5-7-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1975, § 2-12) 
State Law reference- Social security coverage for municipal employees, W. Va. Code § 5-7-5. 
Sec. 2-163. - City as participating public employer; state employees retirement system adopted. 
    The city council, having elected on September 5, 1961, by three-fifths vote of its members, to have the city become a participating public employer and thereby include its eligible officers and employees in the membership of the state employees retirement system, hereby declares that the city shall continue to be a participating public employer and shall conform to all applicable provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 5, art. 10 (W. Va. Code § 5-10-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1975, § 2-13) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to become participating public employers within state public employees retirement system, W. Va. Code §§ 5-10-16, 8-22-1. 
Secs. 2-164-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY MANAGER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Manager, § 36. 

Sec. 2-181. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the city, under the supervision and direction of the mayor, and shall have the authority to supervise and direct the executive work and management of the heads of all departments, including the appointment and removal thereof, with the advice of the Mayor, except as otherwise set forth in this Code. The city manager may prescribe such rules, regulations, and policies as he or she deems necessary or expedient for the conduct of the departments subject to his or her authority, and may negotiate, set, and adjust wages, salaries, and other compensation of city employees subject to annual budget appropriations and the Personnel Rules and Administrative Policies, as promulgated and amended. The city manager shall have the power and authority to revoke, suspend, or amend any rule, regulation, or action promulgated by any officer or employee of any department under his or her supervision or direction. Subject to the provisions of this Code and state and federal law, the city manager shall have the authority to make all contracts for labor, supplies, insurance, and professional services and shall generally perform or oversee the administrative work of the city, shall perform such other duties as council may require of him, and shall possess such other powers and perform such other duties as council may prescribe. 
(Code 1975, § 2-31; Bill No. 7712, 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-182. - Supervision and care of grounds and buildings; leases; improvements. 
    Except as may be specifically provided otherwise, the city manager shall be responsible for the management and maintenance of all real property owned by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-183. - Custodian of certain papers and records. 
    The city manager shall have the custody of all contracts to which the city is a party, all insurance policies, and all books, records and papers relating to the business affairs of the city which are under his supervision. 
(Code 1975, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-184. - Personnel Rules and Administrative Policies; duties and authority. 
    The city manager shall have the discretion and authority to authorize amendments and additions to the Personnel Rules and Administrative Policies upon consultation with the director of human resources and the city attorney and in the manner set forth in this Code. 
(Bill No. 7712, 9-19-2016) 
Secs. 2-185-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY CLERK[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Duties of municipal recorders generally, W. Va. Code § 8-10-3. 

Sec. 2-201. - Custodian of records. 
    The city clerk shall be the custodian of all records, maps, documents and other papers of the city government for which no other custodian is designated; and he shall keep them secure against all hazards and make them available to the public as provided in section 2-332. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34(a)) 
Sec. 2-202. - Contact with public. 
    The office of the city clerk is recognized as the principal point of contact between the public and the city government; and all personnel of the city clerk's office shall provide information and guidance to all orderly persons affected by the provisions of this Code or other ordinances or resolutions of the city council, and to those having business to transact in any city department, office or agency. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34(b)) 
Sec. 2-203. - Other powers, duties. 
    The city clerk shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as may be specified by the mayor or city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34(c)) 
Secs. 2-204-2-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY COLLECTOR 

Sec. 2-221. - General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the city collector to collect and receive all taxes, fees, assessments, and other charges and debts due the city and for which no other city officer is designated as the collector or recipient; and he shall turn over all money so collected and received by him to the city treasurer periodically not less than once each week. 
(Code 1975, § 2-35) 
Sec. 2-222. - Issuance of licenses, permits. 
    The city collector shall issue all city licenses and permits for which no city officer is designated as the issuing officer. 
(Code 1975, § 2-35) 
Secs. 2-223-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CITY SOLICITOR 

Sec. 2-241. - Appointment. 
    There shall be a city solicitor and such number of assistant city solicitors as may be authorized by budgetary appropriation by resolution of the city council, each of whom shall be appointed by and serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor, and who shall receive such compensation as may be prescribed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4838, § 2-36(a), 5-4-1992; Bill No. 7712, 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-242. - City solicitor to be general legal counsel; special municipal council authorized. 
    The city solicitor shall serve as the general legal counsel of the City, shall be the designee of the Mayor for the purposes of W. Va. Code § 8-10-1a, and shall have the authority to employ within the limit of funds appropriated in the city budget for such purpose, assistant city solicitors, and an attorney or firm of attorneys as special municipal counsel, to advise or represent the City in any legal matter. The city solicitor shall supervise and direct all assistant city solicitors and all special municipal counsel employed by city. Consistent with the authority provided in W. Va. Code § 8-10-1a, the authority provided herein may be modified, limited or revoked by the mayor at any time. 
(Ord. No. 4838, § 2-36(b), 5-4-1992; Bill No. 7712, 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-243. - Settlement authority. 
    The city solicitor, upon the advice and consent of the city manager, shall have the authority to settle or otherwise resolve any claim against the city up to $20,000.00 per claim. Consistent with this section, the city solicitor and city manager are further authorized to take any other lawful actions necessary to settle or otherwise resolve claims against the city, including, but not limited to, approving and executing settlement agreements or related documents and facilitating non-monetary reparations by the city in lieu of or in addition to the monetary settlement authority set forth herein. Provided, settlement or other resolution of any claim requiring payment by city of more than $20,000.00 shall be submitted to city council by resolution for consideration and approval by city council. 
(Ord. No. 7518, 4-2-2012; Bill No. 7712, 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 2-244. - Personnel rules and administrative policies; duties and authority. 
    The city solicitor shall review all proposed amendments or additions to the personnel rules and administrative policies, shall advise the city manager and the director of human resources with respect to any such proposed amendment or addition, and shall have such further duties and authority as is necessary and required by this Code. 
(Bill No. 7712, 9-19-2016) 
Secs. 2-245-2-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CITY ENGINEER 

Sec. 2-261. - Responsibilities. 
    The city engineer shall be responsible for all engineering work for the city and shall supervise the planning, designing, constructing and maintenance of city-owned structures, facilities, bridges, roads, water and sewer systems, and all other engineering work and all related activities that may be acquired. 
(Code 1975, § 2-38)

Sec. 2-281. - Powers. 
    The director of public works shall be but is not limited to the administrative head of the cemetery department, incinerator department, landfill department, street department and equipment maintenance department, and shall direct and coordinate the personnel, equipment and activities of these public works departments. 
(Code 1975, § 2-39)

Sec. 2-301. - Duties. 
    The director of the mayor's office of economic and community development shall effect a unified and coordinated effort toward total and complete development of the city in order to provide for a better quality of life for its citizens through improvement of government service and economic growth, and to further coordinate the office of federal and state relations in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-40.1)
