ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC RECORDS 

Sec. 2-331. - Secure maintenance of books, records. 
    All books of account, contracts, insurance policies and other books, records, documents and papers of importance shall be kept on file in fireproof safes or file cabinets in the city hall, or in safety deposit boxes or other fireproof and secure places authorized by the mayor or city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-8) 
Sec. 2-332. - Availability to public of city books and records; protection of books and records. 
(a)  Except as may be provided otherwise by state law, this Code or other ordinance to safeguard the security of license tax returns, personnel records and other confidential information, all records, books, maps, documents and other papers which are maintained on file in any city office shall be open for inspection and use by citizens of the city and others having an interest during all regular business hours, but none shall be removed from the office of its custodian except by authority of the mayor, the city manager or the city council, or pursuant to a valid subpoena duces tecum issuing from a court or officer having jurisdiction in the premises. 
(b)  No person shall, without proper authority as provided in subsection (a) of this section, remove from the office of its custodian any record, book, map, file, document or other paper which is maintained on file in any city office or court, without giving written receipt to the custodian; nor shall any person fail to return any such item to its proper custodian within the time set by the custodian for its return. 
(c)  No person shall willfully destroy, obliterate, secrete, deface, mark upon, disturb the arrangement of, damage or otherwise tamper with any record, book, map, file, document or other paper which is maintained on file in any city office or court. 
(Code 1975, § 2-9) 
State Law reference- Alteration, concealment, larceny or destruction of public records, W. Va. Code §§ 61-5-22, 61-5-23. 
Sec. 2-333. - Fee for copies of records and documents supplied by city clerk to applicants. 
    The city clerk is authorized and directed to charge the sum of $0.20 per page for copies of all records and documents supplied to any person upon request made to the clerk; however, no charge shall be made for such copies supplied to the city or any other governmental unit, or any of their agencies, bureaus, departments, divisions or instrumentalities, and members of the city council for their official use. 
(Code 1975, § 2-10) 
Sec. 2-334. - Public Records Management and Archives Act. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. The council declares that programs for cost efficient and economical management of city records will be to facilitate the incorporation of modern technology and procedures in the day-to-day record-keeping activities of city government and will facilitate and expedite government operations; that records containing information essential to the operation of government and to the protection of the rights and interests of persons must be protected against the destructive effects of all forms of disaster and must be available when needed. It is necessary, therefore, to adopt special provisions for the selection and preservation of historical and essential city records thereby providing for the protection and availability of such information. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  Disaster means any occurrence of fire, flood, storm, earthquake, explosion, epidemic, riot, sabotage or other condition of extreme peril resulting in substantial damage or injury to persons or property within this city, whether such occurrence is caused by an act of God, nature or man, including an enemy of the United States. 
(2)  Records means document, book, paper, photograph, microfilm, sound or video recording or other materials, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or in connection with the transaction of official business. Library and museum materials made or acquired and preserved solely for reference or exhibition purposes, extra copies of documents preserved only for convenience of reference, and stocks or publications and of processed documents are not included within the definition of records as used in this section. 
(3)  City record means: 
(a)  A record of a department, office, commission, board or other agency, however designated, of the city government. 
(b)  A record of the city council. 
(c)  A record of the municipal court. 
(d)  Any record designated or treated as a state record under state law, and which the state mandates a municipality must maintain. 
(4)  Agency means any department, office, commission, boards or other unit, however designated, of the executive branch of city government. 
(5)  Preservation duplicate means a copy of an essential city record which is used for the purpose of preserving such city record pursuant to this section. 
(c)  Categories of records to be preserved. City records which are within the following categories are essential records which shall be preserved pursuant to this section. 
Category A. Records containing information necessary for the day to day operation of government. Historic records showing policy of Charleston to document history. Records containing information necessary to protect the rights and interest of persons or to establish and affirm the powers and duties of governments in the emergency created by a disaster, for the resumption of operations after a disaster. 
(d)  City records administrator. The city manager is hereby designated the city records administrator, hereinafter called the administrator. The administrator shall establish and administer in the executive branch of city government a public records and archives program, which will apply efficient and economical management methods to the creation, utilization, maintenance and retention, preservation and disposal of city records; and shall establish and maintain a program for the selection and preservation of essential city records and shall advise and assist in the establishment of programs for the selection and preservation of essential city records. 
(e)  Duties of administrator. The administrator shall, with due regard for the functions of the departments concerned: 
(1)  Establish standards, procedures, and techniques for effective management of records. 
(2)  Make continuing surveys of paper work operations and recommend improvements in current records management practices including the use of space, equipment and supplies employed in creating, maintaining, storing and servicing records. 
(3)  Establish standards for the preparation of schedules providing for the retention of city records. 
(f)  Duties of department heads. The head of each department shall: 
(1)  Establish standards for the preparation of schedules providing for the retention of city records of continuing value for the prompt and orderly disposal of city records no longer possessing sufficient administrative, legal, or fiscal value to warrant their further keeping. Update and recommend changes to schedule. 
(2)  Select the city records which are essential and determine their category pursuant to this section. In accordance with the rules, and regulations promulgated by the administrator, each person who has custody or control of city records shall (a) inventory the city records in his custody or control; (b) submit to the administrator a report thereon containing such information as the administrator directs and containing these recommendations as to which city records are essential; and (c) bi-annually review his inventory and his report and, if necessary, revise his report so that it is current, accurate and complete. 
(3)  Obtain reports from departments as are required for the administration of the program. Ultimate responsibility rests with department head. The department head will designate a person in each department to work with city coordinator. 
(4)  Establish and maintain an active, continuing program for the economical and efficient management of the records of the department. 
(5)  Make and maintain records containing adequate and proper documentation of the organization, functions, policies, decisions, procedures and essential transactions of the department designed to furnish information to protect the legal and financial rights of the city and of persons directly affected by the department's activities. 
(6)  Submit to the administrator, in accordance with the standards established by him schedules proposing the length of time each city record series warrants retention for administrative, legal or fiscal purpose after it has been received by the department. The head of each department also shall submit lists of city records in his custody that are not needed in the transaction of current business and that do not have sufficient administrative, legal or fiscal value to warrant their further keeping for disposal in conformity with the requirements of subsection (h) of this section. 
(7)  Cooperate with the administrator in the conduct of surveys made by him pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(8)  Comply with the rules, regulations, standards and procedures issued by the administrator. 
(9)  First obtain the administrator's written approval before purchasing or acquiring any equipment or supplies used or to be used to store or preserve records of his department. If such approval is obtained, the department shall submit a requisition to the finance department together with a copy of the administrator's said approval. 
(g)  Rules and regulations. The administrator shall promulgate such rules and regulations concerning the management and selection and preservation of essential city records as are necessary or proper to effectuate the purpose of this section. 
(h)  Essential city records-Preservation duplicates. 
(1)  The administrator may make or cause to be made preservation duplicates or may designate as preservation duplicates existing copies of essential city records. A preservation duplicate shall be durable, accurate, complete and clear, and a preservation duplicate made by means of photography, microphotograph photocopying, film or microfilm shall be made in conformity with the standards prescribed therefore by the administrator and American National Standards Institute. 
(2)  A preservation duplicate made by a photographic, photostatic, microfilm, miniature photographic, or other process which accurately reproduces or forms a durable medium for so reproducing the original, shall have the same force and effect for all purposes as the original record whether the original record is in existence or not. A transcript, exemplification or certified copy of such preservation duplicate shall be deemed for all purposes to be a transcript, exemplification or certified copy of the original record. 
(i)  Safekeeping. 
(1)  The administrator shall prescribe manner of safekeeping of essential city records and preservation duplicates and may establish, with the approval of city council, storage facilities therefore. The administrator may provide for storage at an off-site location. 
(2)  When in the opinion of the administrator, the legally designated or customary location of an essential city record is such that the essential city record may be destroyed or unavailable in the event of a disaster caused by an enemy of the United States: 
(a)  The administrator shall store a preservation duplicate at another location and permit such city record to remain at its legally designated or customary location; or 
(b)  The administrator shall store such city record at a location other than its legally designated or customary location and deposit at the legally designated or customary location a preservation duplicate for use in lieu of the city record; or 
(c)  The administrator may store such city record at a location other than its legally designated or customary location, without providing for a preservation duplicate, upon a determination that it is impracticable to provide for a preservation duplicate and that the city record is not frequently used. Such determination shall be made by the administrator and the regularly designated custodian of such city record, but if they disagree, the determination shall be made by the administrator. 
(3)  The requirements of subsection (2) of this section shall not prohibit the administrator from removing an essential city record or preservation duplicate from the legally designated or customary location of the city record if a disaster caused by an enemy of the United States has occurred or is imminent. 
(j)  Maintenance, inspection and use. 
(1)  The administrator shall properly maintain essential city records and preservation duplicates stored by him. 
(2)  An essential city record or preservation duplicate stored by the administrator may be recalled by the regularly designated custodian of the city record for temporary use when necessary for the proper conduct of his office and shall be returned by such custodian to the administrator immediately after such use. 
(3)  When an essential city record is stored by the administrator, the administrator, upon request of the regularly designated custodian of the city record, shall provide for its inspection, or for the making or certification of copies thereof, and such copies when certified by the administrator shall have the same force and effect as if certified by the regularly designated custodian. 
(k)  Confidential records. When a city record is required by law to be treated in a confidential manner and is an essential city record, the administrator in effectuating the purpose of this section with respect to such city record, shall protect its confidential nature. 
(l)  Review of program. The administrator shall review periodically but at least once a year the program for the selection and preservation of essential city records, including the classification of records and the provisions for preservation duplicates, and for safekeeping of essential city records or preservation duplicates to ensure that the purposes of this section are accomplished. 
(m)  Disposal of records. No record shall be destroyed or otherwise disposed of by any department of the city, unless it is determined by the administrator and the city clerk that the record has no further administrative, legal, fiscal, research or historical value. The most current copy of The West Virginia Municipality Records Manual is hereby designated by council as retention and disposition schedule of the City of Charleston. The city may amend retention schedule by approval. 
(n)  Destruction of nonrecord materials. Nonrecord materials or materials not included within the definition of records as contained in this section may, if not otherwise prohibited by law, be destroyed at any time by the department in possession of such materials without the prior approval of the administrator. The administrator may formulate procedures and interpretations to guide in the disposal of non-record materials. 
(Bill No. 6859, § 1-14, 11-5-2001) 
Secs. 2-335-2-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-17(4); any ordinance authorizing or approving any contract, deed or agreement saved from repeal, § 1-17(5); taxation, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation and finance, W. Va. Code § 8-13-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-361. - Fiscal reports, accounts to conform to fiscal year; "fiscal year" defined. 
    All fiscal reports, settlements, accounts and statements of the city and of city officers shall conform to the fiscal year, which begins on July 1 of each calendar year and terminates at the close of business June 30 of the next succeeding calendar year. 
(Code 1975, § 2-41) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 8-13-17. 
Sec. 2-362. - Supervision of finances by finance director. 
    The finance director shall direct the city auditor in the proper keeping of all accounts and issuing of warrants and shall see that the books pertaining to the funds and finances of the city are properly kept; and it shall be his duty, whenever required to do so, to furnish to the city council any statement of the financial condition of the city or of any particular fund or the fund apportioned to any particular purpose at any time. 
(Code 1975, § 2-42) 
Sec. 2-363. - City funds and provisions governing such funds. 
    The city treasurer shall keep the money of the city in such accounts as may be required or authorized by federal or state law, the city's Charter, this Code, or other ordinance or resolution of the city council; and the term "accounts" shall be interchangeable with the term "funds" as, for example, the "sinking fund," the "withholding tax fund" and the "general fund," subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  Revenue derived from municipal public works financed by outstanding revenue bonds of the city, in sufficient sums as may be required to meet the principal and interest payments on such bonds and other related finance charges, as provided in W. Va. Code § 8-16-17, and all money arising from any special levy for sinking fund purposes on bonds of the city outstanding (except for interest on special paving and sewer bonds issued under the provisions of W. Va. Code § 8-18-14) and such sums as may be set aside by the city council to make up any deficit in the sinking fund shall be credited to the sinking fund, in the same proportion as fixed in the published estimates made by the city council and upon which such levy was laid, or in the proportion set out by the council in any order directing a deposit to be made to the credit of such fund to meet any deficit. 
(2)  All money collected on account of interest and sinking fund from assessments against property owners for sewering and paving improvements made under the provisions of W. Va. Code § 8-18-14 shall be deposited to the credit of the paving and sewer fund. 
(3)  All money arising from the sale of cemetery lots, digging graves, rights-of-way through the cemetery, contributions to the improvement of the cemetery, and funds raised for the improvement of any road or walk in the cemetery shall be deposited to the cemetery fund. 
State Law reference- Special fund for money raised for a public works which, for any reason, cannot be presently constructed, W. Va. Code § 8-13-21. 
(4)  All deposits which have heretofore been legally diverted by ordinance or lawful order of the city council towards the establishment of special funds for specific purposes shall be deposited to the credit of the special funds to which under such ordinance they properly belong. 
(5)  All the money received into the treasury from all other sources whatever shall be deposited to the credit of the general fund; provided, the city council may establish a capital reserve fund, to consist of unexpended balances of other funds which may be transferred by order of the city council, subject to the requirements and limitations imposed by W. Va. Code § 8-13-19. 
(Code 1975, § 2-43) 
Sec. 2-364. - Disbursement of funds to chief of police. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall, upon written request by the mayor or his designee, disburse to the chief of police or his designee funds, not to exceed $100,000.00, from the municipal accounts. These funds are not to be expended by the chief of police, his designee or any agent of the police department, but are to be maintained, secured and utilized, under guidelines established by the chief of police, as a necessary means of investigating criminal activity. These funds shall be returned to the city treasurer for redeposit to municipal accounts within 72 hours of the initial disbursement. 
(b)  The policies and procedures necessary for the disbursement, maintenance and security of such funds and the forms necessary to implement such procedures shall be promulgated by the chief of police. These policies, procedures and forms shall be submitted to and approved by the finance committee of the city council, the city treasurer and the city manager. Upon disbursement of any funds pursuant to this section, copies of the necessary procedural forms shall be maintained in the office of the city treasurer for inspection by the proper officials of the city government. 
(Code 1975, § 2-43.1) 
Sec. 2-365. - Additional provisions as to special funds; establishment of escrows. 
    In addition to the funds provided in this division, the city council shall have power to establish special funds for any specific purposes, such as, for example, the building of a certain sewer, or paving of certain portions of a street, the funds to be raised by the parties interested in the improvements and deposited to the credit of such special fund and to be expended only for the purposes of the fund. The city treasurer shall also be authorized to accept any money in escrow under any legal contract made by the city council or city manager, and hold and dispose of such money according to the terms of the escrow agreement or contract. 
(Code 1975, § 2-44) 
Sec. 2-366. - Money to be deposited in banks designated as city depository, and receipts for deposits. 
    All city money or money due the city from any source whatever shall be deposited as required by section 58 of the city's Charter, in banks designated by the city council as city depositories, to the credit of "the City of Charleston ___________ Fund," designating the fund to which the money should properly go. The city treasurer shall, either in person or through some official of the bank, issue a receipt for all such deposits showing the date of the deposit, the amount deposited, by whom deposited and the fund to which it was credited. 
(Code 1975, § 2-45) 
Charter reference- Depositories, § 58. 
State Law reference- Depositories, W. Va. Code § 8-13-22a. 
Sec. 2-367. - Purposes for which expenditures may be made from the several funds of the city. 
(a)  No expenditures from the sinking fund shall be made except for a purpose lawfully ordained or ordered by the city council and in conformity with the provisions of W. Va. Code § 8-16-17; but the city treasurer, under direction of the city council, shall transfer such fund to the state sinking fund commission as provided by W. Va. Code § 8-16-17. 
(b)  No expenditure from the paving and sewer fund shall be made except for a purpose for which assessments were levied against property owners or for payments of principal, interest and other charges on outstanding bonds of the city in conformity with the provisions of W. Va. Code § 8-18-14. 
(c)  All other money coming into the treasury of the city from any source whatever (except from special funds) and deposited to the credit of the general fund may be used by the city in paying the expenses of the city government and for such improvements of city property, streets, sewers, parks and public buildings and places as may be justified by the condition of the city's finances and the laws and ordinances governing the levying, collection and expenditure of the city funds. 
(d)  No expenditure shall be made from any special fund or fund held in escrow except for a purpose for which such fund or escrow was established. 
(Code 1975, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-368. - Disbursement of general fund; contracts in excess of estimated revenue. 
    The general fund at the time of laying the annual tax levy shall be apportioned by the city council for the several purposes for which it was levied or collected, and for the general needs of the city government, including any deficit in a special tax levied for the sinking fund, but not including special funds; and the council shall, as nearly as possible, keep the expenses of each department or branch of the city service within the limits of such apportionment; but if a saving can be made in the expenses of any one department, such saving may be applied to any deficit which may arise in the apportionment for any other department, and any excess of revenue over and above the estimated collections from any given source during the fiscal year may likewise be applied to any such deficit; but under no circumstances shall the city expend or contract for the expenditure of more money than the amount estimated each year in the annual estimate published in March of each year, as the probable receipts for the fiscal year, plus any money received into the treasury by reason of collections for such fiscal year to the credit of the general fund, in excess of the amount estimated to be received from any such known source of revenue. 
(Code 1975, § 2-47) 
State Law reference- March meetings of local tax levying bodies, W. Va. Code §§ 11-8-9, 11-8-14. 
Sec. 2-369. - Accounts of auditor. 
    An account shall be kept by the city auditor showing the warrants drawn on the several funds each day, which account shall be kept posted up to within 40 hours of the time when the last warrant was drawn; and the account shall be consolidated at the end of each fiscal year into a report as prescribed by W. Va. Code ch. 6, art. 9 (W. Va. Code § 6-9-1 et seq.). Separate accounts shall also be kept by the auditor with all persons from whom the city has purchased supplies or who have performed any work for the city exclusive of those paid on the payroll of the several departments. 
(Code 1975, § 2-48) 
State Law reference- Applicability of above-cited statute to municipalities, W. Va. Code § 8-13-18. 
Sec. 2-370. - Annual financial statement. 
(a)  The city auditor, within four weeks after the beginning of each fiscal year, shall prepare on a form to be prescribed by the state tax commissioner and cause to be published a sworn statement revealing: 
(1)  The receipts and expenditures of the city during the previous fiscal year arranged under descriptive headings; 
(2)  The name of each person who received more than $50.00 from any fund during the previous fiscal year, together with the amount received and the purpose for which paid; and 
(3)  All debts of the city, the purpose for which each debt was contracted, its due date, and to what date the interest on the debt has been paid. 
Such statement shall be published as a class I legal advertisement in compliance with the provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 59, art. 3 (W. Va. Code § 59-3-1 et seq.), and the publication area for such publication shall be the city. 
(b)  The city clerk shall transmit to any resident of the city, upon request, a copy of any published statement for the fiscal year designated, supplemented by a document listing the names of each person who received less than $50.00 from any fund during such fiscal year and showing the amount paid to each and the purpose for which paid. 
(c)  The statement required by subsection (a) of this section shall be sworn to by the city clerk, the mayor and two councilmembers. As soon as practicable following the close of the fiscal year, a copy of any required statement shall be filed by the city clerk with the state tax commissioner and the clerks of the county court and circuit court of the county. 
(Code 1975, § 2-49) 
State Law reference- Required report, W. Va. Code § 8-13-23. 
Sec. 2-371. - Vouchers. 
    It shall be the duty of the city auditor to take a voucher from every person to whom a city warrant is issued, except for warrants issued to officers and employees of the city working on fixed salaries or per diem, and except warrants issued on payrolls of departments, and to file the voucher in a jacket in his office; and the jacket shall show the name of the person to whom the warrant was drawn, the number of the warrant, the amount and date thereof, and the fund to which it should be charged. No person shall remove any of the vouchers from the office of the auditor for any purpose; but all books and vouchers may be inspected there at any reasonable time by any committee of the city council, by any member of the council or by any responsible citizen upon request made by him to the council and under the personal supervision of the auditor. 
(Code 1975, § 2-50) 
Sec. 2-372. - Orders on the city treasurer. 
    No money, except such as may be paid on city bonds and coupons, shall be paid by the city except upon an order upon the city treasurer, drawn by the city auditor and countersigned by the mayor. 
(Code 1975, § 2-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 8-13-22. 
Sec. 2-373. - Authority of city auditor upon application for order to pay out money when applicant is indebted to city. 
    The city auditor, upon application for and prior to drawing an order on the city treasurer to pay out money to any person entitled to such money, may, in the exercise of sound discretion, first ascertain whether such person is delinquent in the payment of any city tax or is otherwise indebted to the city, insofar as such indebtedness, if any, may appear on the city's records. Upon so ascertaining that such person is in fact indebted to the city, the city auditor shall then take proper action pursuant to the established administrative and accounting procedures to apply all or such part of the amount to which such person is entitled to receive from the city to the full or partial payment, as the case may be, of his debt to the city; and if the amount such person is entitled to receive from the city exceeds the amount of his indebtedness to the city, the auditor shall then draw an order on the city treasurer to pay out to such person the amount of such excess; and, in either case, the auditor shall give to such person a memorandum of the entire transaction. 
(Code 1975, § 2-52) 
Sec. 2-374. - Splitting orders; sufficient funds in treasury. 
    The city auditor is forbidden to divide or split any order allowed except by special direction of the city council, and no order shall be drawn upon the city treasury unless there is sufficient funds in the treasury appropriated or otherwise authorized to be expended for the purpose and in the amount for which the order is drawn. 
(Code 1975, § 2-53) 
Sec. 2-375. - Order register. 
    The city auditor shall keep in an order register the date, number and amount of all city orders issued, with columns showing the funds on which drawn and the purpose for which drawn. Upon every settlement made with the city treasurer, the canceled orders surrendered by him shall be compared by the auditor with the register; and all orders thus found to be paid shall be checked off with red ink, in order to show the amount of outstanding orders. 
(Code 1975, § 2-54) 
Sec. 2-376. - Loss of order upon city treasurer. 
    In cases where a city order drawn upon the city treasurer has been lost by or stolen from the holder, the person suffering such a loss may have issued to him, by the finance director, a duplicate of the order on the following conditions: Such party must file with the city auditor an affidavit, setting forth the facts and circumstances of the loss, and specifically describing the order, and he must, moreover, execute to the city, a bond, with security to be approved by the finance director, in a penalty of twice the amount of the order, to indemnify the city in the event of the payment of the order by the city treasurer, or loss by the city in any manner through the issuance of such duplicate order. As soon as the affidavit is filed with the auditor, it shall be the duty of the auditor's office to furnish to the treasurer a memorandum of the loss or theft of the order, stating the date, number, payee and amount of the order, and the fund upon which it is drawn, and notify the treasurer not to pay such order. 
(Code 1975, § 2-55) 
Sec. 2-377. - Self-insured status for workers' compensation. 
(a)  The city council, as long as the city has elected to pay compensation and expenses directly under the provisions of W. Va. Code § 23-2-9, shall appropriate each year sufficient funds in an amount to pay into the state workers' compensation fund the city's proper proportion of the expenses of the workers' compensation commissioner, in administering the fund, the required amounts into the surplus fund for the coverage of catastrophe and second injury liability, and to pay all workers' compensation benefits anticipated to be payable that year. In addition to the appropriation of such moneys, the city council shall authorize all other necessary procedures to ensure that all workers' compensation payments shall be paid promptly to its employees or fatally injured employees' dependents and shall direct the purchase of excess insurance for the purpose of indemnifying the city against losses per accident in excess of a specific retention level to be determined by the mayor and, for the purpose of indemnifying the city against annual losses in the aggregate, in excess of a retention level to be determined by the mayor. 
(b)  If at any time the city determines that it is no longer in the best interest of the city, its employees or its citizens to continue to pay compensation and expenses directly under the provisions of W. Va. Code § 23-2-9, the city shall immediately advise the state workers' compensation commissioner that it has elected to discontinue paying such compensation and expenses directly as to future claims and shall immediately begin paying into the workers' compensation fund the premiums required to comply with the provisions of W. Va. Code §§ 23-2-1 and 23-2-5. If the city shall elect to discontinue paying such compensation and expenses directly, it shall, nevertheless, remain liable to and shall pay such compensation and expenses directly in claims arising prior to the election to resume payment of such premiums into the workers' compensation fund. 
(Code 1975, § 2-55.1) 
State Law reference- Employer self-insurance option, W. Va. Code § 23-2-9. 
Sec. 2-378. - Bonds for faithful performance of contracts and franchises. 
    All bonds given for the faithful performance of the terms of any contract or franchise granted by the city shall be executed by competent corporate surety duly authorized to do business in the state and shall be approved as to form and legality by the city solicitor and by the city manager as to amount, sufficiency and acceptability of the surety. 
(Code 1975, § 2-11) 
Secs. 2-379-2-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUDGET[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for budgeting, accounting and record keeping, W. Va. Code § 8-13-18; accounting and reporting requirements, W. Va. Code § 6-9-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-401. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Spending officer means the executive head of a spending unit, or a person designated by him. 
    Spending unit means a department, agency or institution of the city government for which an appropriation is requested, or to which an appropriation is made by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-56) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-402. - Powers and duties of finance director. 
(a)  The finance director, under the immediate direction and supervision of the mayor, shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)  Exercise general supervision of and make rules and regulations for the government of his department. 
(2)  Prepare, in accordance with this division, requests for appropriations, estimates of cost, and the forms and contents of the city budget for submission to the city council. 
(3)  Administer the budget in accordance with this division. 
(4)  Serve as staff agency to the mayor and city council in the consideration of requests for appropriations and the preparation of the budget document. 
(5)  Make such investigations and submit such reports as the mayor or city council may require. 
(6)  Make a continuous study of municipal expenditures and make such recommendations to the mayor for the more economical use of municipal funds as he shall find practicable. 
(7)  Render assistance to spending officers with respect to the fiscal affairs of spending units. 
(8)  Make an annual report to the mayor and city council with respect to the conduct of his department and the administration of the municipal finances. 
(9)  Exercise such other powers as are vested in him by this division or which may be appropriate to the discharge of his duties. 
(b)  The finance director shall keep himself informed as to the overall financial condition of the city and the status of each of the several city funds, as well as the outstanding indebtedness of the city, and money and securities due and payable to the city and the progress being made in their collection. 
(c)  Records, reports and other forms of paper work, as well as procedures, established by the finance director shall conform to all applicable requirements and policies of the state tax commissioner, as provided in W. Va. Code §§ 6-9-6 and 11-1-2. 
(Code 1975, § 2-57) 
Sec. 2-403. - Requests for appropriations. 
(a)  When, by and to whom submitted. The head of each spending unit shall, on or before February 20 of each year, submit to the finance director a request for appropriations for the fiscal year next ensuing. 
(b)  Contents. A request for appropriations for a spending unit shall specify and itemize in written form: 
(1)  A statement showing the amount and kinds of revenue and receipts, actually collected as well as anticipated, for the use of the city during the current fiscal year. 
(2)  A statement, by purposes and objects, of the amount of appropriations requested for the spending unit for the next ensuing fiscal year. 
(3)  A statement showing the actual and anticipated expenditures of this spending unit for the current fiscal year and estimated expenditures for the next ensuing fiscal year, itemized by purposes and objects, including those from regular and supplementary appropriations, federal aid, private contributions, transfers, allotments from an emergency or contingent fund, and any other expenditures made by or for the spending unit. 
(4)  A statement showing the number, classification and compensation of persons employed by the spending unit, distinguishing between regular, special and casual employees during the last preceding fiscal year and during the next fiscal year. 
(5)  A statement showing in detail the purposes for which increased amounts of appropriations, if any, are requested, and giving a justification statement for the expenditure of the increased amount. A construction or other improvement request shall show in detail the kind and scope of construction or improvement requested. 
(6)  A statement of money claims against the city arising out of the activities of the spending unit. 
(7)  Such other information as the finance director may request. 
(c)  Form. The finance director shall specify the form and the detail of itemization of requests for appropriations and statements to be submitted by a spending unit. He shall furnish blank forms for this purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 2-58) 
State Law reference- Information required by municipal governing bodies each March for levy estimating purposes, W. Va. Code § 11-8-14. 
Sec. 2-404. - Appropriations for other than spending units. 
    A person or organization, other than a spending officer, who desires to request a general appropriation in the city budget shall submit his request to the finance director on or before February 20. The request shall be in the form prescribed by the director and shall be accompanied by a justification statement. 
(Code 1975, § 2-59) 
Sec. 2-405. - Examination of requests for appropriations. 
(a)  The finance director shall examine the requests of a spending unit with respect to requested appropriations, itemization, sufficiency of justification statements, and accuracy and completeness of all other information which the spending officer is required to submit. 
(b)  If the finance director finds a request, report or statement of a spending unit inaccurate, incomplete or inadequate, he shall consult with the spending officer of the unit and require the submission of the requests in proper form and content. The director shall assist spending officers in the preparation of their requests. 
(Code 1975, § 2-60) 
Sec. 2-406. - Preparation of tentative budget and submittal to city council. 
(a)  Between February 20 and March 1 of each year, the finance director shall examine and collate all requests for appropriations and prepare for consideration of the city council a tentative budget for the ensuing fiscal year. This tentative budget shall conform to the requirements for the levy estimate, as set out in W. Va. Code § 11-8-14; and it shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the state tax commissioner and shall, inter alia, state the estimated amounts for the next fiscal year with respect to: 
(1)  Appropriations requested by each spending unit and requested general appropriations. 
(2)  Amounts and purposes of appropriations requested other than for spending units of the city. 
(3)  Revenue of each of the funds of the city. 
(4)  A summary statement of requests and revenues showing the amount of an anticipated surplus or deficit. 
(b)  At the first meeting of the city council in March of each year, the finance director shall present the tentative budget to the council, together with such supporting data as may be necessary for a clear understanding of, and his written comments and recommendations on the budget; and all such matters shall then be referred by the mayor to the committee on finance and claims, with instructions to submit its report on the budget at the meeting of the council required to be held pursuant to W. Va. Code §§ 11-8-9 and 11-8-14. 
(Code 1975, § 2-61) 
Sec. 2-407. - Powers of director in administration of expenditures. 
    The finance director shall supervise and control the expenditures of appropriations made by the city council. The expenditure of an appropriation made by the council shall be conditioned upon compliance by the department with the provisions of this article, and each appropriation made by the council shall be expended only in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1975, § 2-62) 
Sec. 2-408. - Reports on revenue collections. 
    The finance director shall ascertain the collection of the revenue of the city and shall determine each quarter of the fiscal year the proportion which the amount actually collected bears to the collection estimated for that period. The director shall certify to the mayor and city council, as soon as possible after the close of each quarter, and at such other times as the mayor and council may request, the condition of the municipal revenues and of the several funds of the city. For the purpose of this section the director shall have the authority to require all necessary estimates and reports from any spending unit of the city government. 
(Code 1975, § 2-63) 
Sec. 2-409. - Management accounting. 
    The finance director shall formulate the requirements of a system of management accounting for the planning, management and control of city expenditures. The requirements shall include methods for recording the collection of all income, amounts available for expenditure, obligation, encumbrances and disbursements for each department. The director shall certify such requirements to the state tax commissioner and obtain his approval before its adoption. The mayor and finance director shall incorporate the requirements into a system of accounting for the city government. The system shall include the accounts to be kept by the finance director, the city auditor, the city treasurer, city collector and manager. The mayor shall require its use by all spending units. 
(Code 1975, § 2-64) 
Sec. 2-410. - Expenditure schedules. 
(a)  Prior to the beginning of each fiscal year, the spending officer of a spending unit shall submit to the finance director a detailed expenditure schedule for the ensuing fiscal year. The schedule shall be submitted in such form and at such time as the director may require. The schedule shall show: 
(1)  A proposed monthly rate of expenditure for amounts appropriated for personal services. 
(2)  A proposed quarterly rate of expenditure for amounts appropriated for current expenses and for equipment, repairs and alterations. 
(3)  A proposed yearly plan of expenditure for amounts appropriated for buildings and lands. 
(b)  The finance director may accept a differently itemized expenditure schedule from a spending unit to which the requirements of this section do not apply. 
(c)  The finance director shall consult with and assist spending officers in the preparation of expenditure schedules. 
(Code 1975, § 2-65) 
Sec. 2-411. - Examination and approval of schedules; expenditures to accord. 
(a)  The finance director shall examine the expenditure schedule of each spending unit and if he finds that it conforms to the requirements of this division and is in accordance with sound fiscal policy, he shall approve the schedule. 
(b)  The expenditure of appropriations made to a spending unit shall be only in accordance with the approved expenditure schedule unless the schedule is amended with the consent of the finance director, or unless appropriations are reduced by the city council prior to their expenditure. 
(Code 1975, § 2-66) 
Sec. 2-412. - Reserve for emergencies as part of expenditure schedule. 
    The finance director, with the approval of the city council, may require that an expenditure schedule provide for a reserve for emergencies out of the total amount appropriated to the spending unit. The amount of the reserve shall be determined by the director in consultation with the spending officer. 
(Code 1975, § 2-67) 
Sec. 2-413. - Reports by spending units. 
    A spending unit shall submit to the finance director such reports with respect to the work and expenditures of the unit as the director may request for the purposes of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 2-68) 
Sec. 2-414. - Expenditure procedure. 
(a)  No expenditures shall be made and no obligation shall be incurred on behalf of the city until after it has been approved by the finance director. Any expenditure made and any obligation incurred by any official or employee of the city not in accordance with this section shall be an unlawful act. 
(b)  The spending officer and the city manager shall prepare and submit to the finance director a requisition showing the amount, purpose and appropriation from which the expenditure is requested. 
(c)  The finance director shall examine the requisition and determine whether the amount conforms to the provisions of this article and to sound fiscal policy. 
(d)  If the finance director approves the requisition, he shall encumber the proper account in the amount of the requisition and shall transmit the requisition to the manager for purchase in accordance with law. 
(Code 1975, § 2-69) 
Sec. 2-415. - Requisition for purchases. 
    If a requisition is a request for purchase, the finance director, after encumbering the proper account of the spending unit, shall transmit the requisition to the city manager for purchase in accordance with law. 
(Code 1975, § 2-70) 
Secs. 2-416-2-440. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOND ISSUES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Public bonded indebtedness, W. Va. Code § 13-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-441. - Authorization for issuance. 
    The city may issue its bonds as provided by law, but no bonds shall ever be issued by the city unless their issuance shall have been authorized by a proper ordinance and in strict conformity with and subject to all of the limitations and conditions as set out in the constitution and statutes of the state governing the issuance and sale of municipal bonds. 
(Code 1975, § 2-71) 
Sec. 2-442. - Sinking fund. 
    Whenever any bond of the city is issued, the sinking fund and interest fund created for the liquidation of the principal and interest of the bond shall, as fast as collected, be paid into the hands of the city treasurer to the credit of these funds, and shall then be held by the treasurer in trust and inviolate for the purposes for which the funds are created; and the funds shall cease to be subject to the order of the city council; except, however, the treasurer may transfer such funds to the state municipal bond commission, as provided by law. 
(Code 1975, § 2-72) 
State Law reference- Sinking funds required, W. Va. Code § 8-16-17. 
Secs. 2-443-2-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CONTRACTS AND PURCHASES[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Purchasing and lease authority, W. Va. Code §§ 8-10-10, 8-12-11. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-461. - Purchase of supplies and materials. 
(a)  All supplies and materials for the various departments of the city government, not exceeding at any one time the sum of $25,000.00, shall be purchased by the city manager, and every reasonable precaution shall be taken to procure the supplies and materials at the very lowest price possible consistent with good service and quality. All such purchases shall be made upon requisition signed by the officer in charge of the department for which the supplies or materials are needed, and filed with the city manager, who shall thereupon direct his/her order to the person from whom it is proposed to purchase the supplies or materials, requiring him/her to deliver the supplies to the person in charge of the department for which ordered, and the supplier shall make out his bill at the contract price, on a blank form attached to order and furnished therewith by the manager, and shall send the bill with the goods to the officer in charge of the department for which they were ordered; and it shall be the duty of the officer to examine the goods delivered and the quantity thereof; and if he/she finds the quantity to be as stated in the order and the quality first class or of the grade ordered, he/she shall endorse the bill with a statement that the goods have been received and the quantity and quality found to be correct and shall return the bill and the order upon which it was furnished to the merchant or person making the same, who shall file it with the city manager for approval and authorization for payment. If found incorrect, or if the quality be found below the standard and grade ordered, the officer in charge shall refuse to accept the goods and shall notify the manager to that effect, and the person furnishing the goods shall be notified by the officer in charge of the department that the goods can only remain where delivered at the risk of the person delivering. 
(b)  The purchase of supplies and materials for the various departments of the city government exceeding at any one time the sum of $25,000.00 shall be approved by the city council, and thereupon the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall become applicable. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude the purchase by the city of materials, supplies and equipment by agreement between the city and state director of the division of purchases of the department of finance and administration, as provided in West Virginia Code § 8-12-10(a). 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall preclude the city manager from purchasing supplies and materials without receiving approval from city council where, in the judgment of the city manager, the failure to immediately purchase supplies and materials, prior to securing council approval, would result in a condition of extreme peril resulting in substantial damages or injury to persons or property within this city, whether such occurrence is caused by an act of God, nature or man, including an enemy of the United States. 
(e)  No contract may be authorized to any business or individual that is delinquent in any financial obligation to the city or is not operating with all required licenses and permits. 
(Code 1975, § 2-83; Ord. No. 4898, 12-2-1993; Bill. No. 6860, § 2-83, 11-5-2001; Bill. No. 6847, § 2-83, 9-17-2001; Bill No. 6875, § 2-83, 1-22-2002; Bill No. 7095, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 7519, 4-2-2012) 
Sec. 2-462. - City manager to purchase all supplies and materials. 
    It shall be the duty of the city manager to supervise the purchase of all supplies and materials necessary for the use of the city or for any and all departments of the city government. 
(Code 1975, § 2-84) 
Sec. 2-463. - Procurement standards for federally funded projects. 
    For any procurements for projects or services in which federal funds are involved, the method of procurement for projects or services shall be one of the following: 
(1)  Small purchase procedures; 
(2)  Competitive sealed bids; 
(3)  Competitive negotiation; or 
(4)  Noncompetitive negotiation. 
    Procurement under any of these methods shall be made pursuant to the procedures set forth in Circular A-102 of the Office of Management and Budget, dated August 15, 1979, and as thereafter amended. 
(Code 1975, § 2-84.2; Bill No. 7379, 3-3-2009) 
Secs. 2-464-2-470. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Bids 

Sec. 2-471. - When advertising for bids required; publication of advertisement, time for opening of bids; letting of contracts; contracts to be in writing. 
(a)  Whenever any contract is proposed to be entered into by the city involving the expenditure of more than $25,000.00, except where such contract involves the rendering of professional services or where such contract is for materials and supplies as referenced in 2-461, the city manager shall publish an advertisement calling for bids for this work, unless it is decided to do this work with city personnel or others employed by the city for such purposes. The time for opening such bids shall not be less than ten days from the date of the first publication of the advertisement. The advertisement shall be printed once a week for two successive weeks in two newspapers of opposite politics, and of general circulation and published in the city, preceding the time of opening the bids. The council shall reserve the right to reject any and all bids, but the contract, if let, must be let to the lowest responsible bidder. No contract shall be awarded to any bidder that is delinquent in any financial obligation to the city or is not operating with all required licenses and permits; Provided; that nothing herein is to effect the procurement procedures for design build projects which are governed by West Virginia Code §5-22A-1 et seq., or the procurement procedures for architectural or engineering services which are governed by West Virginia Code § 5G-1-1 et seq. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall preclude the city manager from entering into contracts without first advertising for bids and receiving council approval where, in the judgment of the city manager, the failure to immediately enter into a contract, would result in a condition of extreme peril resulting in substantial damages or injury to persons or property within this city, whether such occurrence is caused by an act of God, nature or man, including an enemy of the United States. 
(Code 1975, § 2-73; Bill No. 6846, § 2-73, 9-17-2001; Bill No. 6874, § 2-73, 1-7-2002; Bill No. 7095, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 7519, 4-2-2012) 
Sec. 2-472. - Contents of advertisements for bids. 
    Notice to bidders shall state: 
(1)  The nature of the work; 
(2)  The place where the plans and specifications and forms of contract may be seen; 
(3)  The amount of cash or bond to be deposited with the city treasurer or city manager as required; 
(4)  The time up to which the bids shall be received and the hour and place of opening the bids; and 
(5)  The right of the city council to reject any and all bids. 
(Code 1975, § 2-74) 
Sec. 2-473. - Additional invitations and advertising soliciting bids. 
    Nothing in section 2-471 shall preclude the city council from directing that invitations to bid shall also be given to contractors in other localities believed to be qualified to perform the work sought to be performed, or from causing additional advertisements from being published in other localities; however, all such invitations and advertisements shall conform to the requirements of section 2-472, and no prospective bidder shall be given any information not given to all other prospective bidders. 
(Code 1975, § 2-75) 
Sec. 2-474. - Submission of bids. 
    Each bid for work under this division shall be made upon a blank form to be furnished by the city manager and shall be placed in a sealed envelope addressed to the manager and endorsed "Proposals for ___________." Each bid shall be signed by the bidder or by an authorized officer or agent where the bid is by a firm or corporation. The bid shall not be opened before the time and hour fixed in the notice. 
(Code 1975, § 2-76) 
Sec. 2-475. - Deposits by bidders. 
(a)  The amount of the cash or bond deposited shall be equal to five percent of the total cost of the work as estimated by the city manager; however, no deposit shall be less than $25.00. 
(b)  The deposit so made shall be conditioned that the successful bidder shall enter into a written contract to do the work bid for according to the terms of his bid and shall furnish approved security within ten days after the award has been made and the successful bidder notified. 
(Code 1975, § 2-77) 
Sec. 2-476. - When bidder's deposit forfeited. 
    If any bidder to whom a contract shall have been awarded fails to enter into a contract and to furnish approved security within the time specified, his deposit shall be forfeited to the city; and the city manager may advertise for new bids. 
(Code 1975, § 2-78) 
Sec. 2-477. - Disposition of deposits. 
    Whenever a contract for public work or supplies has been awarded, the city manager shall be authorized to refund the deposit of each unsuccessful bidder. The deposit of the successful bidder shall be retained until the contract shall have been entered into and approved by the manager. 
(Code 1975, § 2-79) 
Sec. 2-478. - Opening of bids. 
    No bids shall be opened and read by the city manager before the time indicated in the advertisement. 
(Code 1975, § 2-80) 
Sec. 2-479. - Rejection of bids. 
    If in any bid blanks are not properly filled up so as to make the bid complete and without an ambiguity as to its intent and meaning, or if a bid has any alteration or erasure upon it, or if it is not properly signed, or if the certificate of deposit has not been enclosed with the bid as provided, the bid shall be rejected. 
(Code 1975, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-480. - Action upon bids; award of contract; authority to reject all bids. 
    Upon the opening and consideration of all bids by the city manager, he shall submit them to the city council, together with his calculations and recommendations, to the city council for appropriate action with respect to awarding the contract. The council or the manager shall have the authority to reject all bids. 
(Code 1975, § 2-82) 
Secs. 2-481-2-510. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- City housing commission, § 14-91 et seq.; Spring Hill Cemetery commission, § 22-61 et seq.; board of solicitation review, § 26-1; Shelton-Sentz Neighborhood Redevelopment Select Committee, § 30-1; rehabilitation fund commission, § 30-64; emergency services council, § 42-32; firemen's civil service commission, § 54-46; human rights commission, § 62-41 et seq.; citizens commission of the Charleston Mounted Police Patrol, § 66-111 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 82-81 et seq.; municipal planning commission, § 90-31 et seq.; sanitary board, § 118-121 et seq.; committees for rules of council, app. A, rule no. 2; board of zoning appeals, app. B, § 26-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-511-2-530. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-531. - Created; composition; appointment, term and compensation of members; filling vacancies. 
    There is created the "Municipal Beautification Commission of Charleston." The commission shall consist of 12 members who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. All members shall be appointed for terms of three years each and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified; and, to provide staggered terms of office, four members shall be appointed on or before September 19 of each year, to take office on September 19 of the year in which appointed. Vacancies occurring other than by reason of expiration of term of office shall be filled for the unexpired term only. Members shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1975, § 2-152) 
Sec. 2-532. - Annual organizational meeting; officers; rules; meetings. 
    At its first meeting after the appointment of new members each year, the beautification commission shall elect from its membership a chairman, secretary and such other officers as it determines to be necessary for the performance of its duties. The commission shall adopt such rules and hold such meetings as shall be necessary or convenient for the transaction of its business. 
(Code 1975, § 2-153) 
Sec. 2-533. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the beautification commission to advise and recommend to the mayor or the city council such programs or projects as would, in the opinion of the commission, improve the beauty and general welfare of the city. 
(b)  The mayor or the council may request the advice or cooperation of the commission for any project or program connected with the beautification, cleanliness or general welfare of the city. 
(c)  The commission shall submit an annual report to the mayor, generally outlining its program and progress during the previous year. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the commission to maintain Davis Park, Slack Plaza, Brawley Walkway, Shanklin Park, Elk River Park and Ruffner Park and to promulgate rules and regulations for the use of such parks. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the commission to review all proposed supergraphics to ensure that such supergraphics are in keeping with the intended location and are free from expressed or implied commercial, political or religious advertisement. 
(f)  The commission shall approve recommendations for expenditures from the municipal beautification project fund. 
(g)  The commission shall, upon recommendation of the department head, approve the citywide consulting horticulturalist and make this recommendation to the finance committee and the city council. 
(h)  The commission shall serve as the tree board for the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-154; Ord. No. 6298, § 2-154, 5-15-2000) 
Sec. 2-534. - Expenses of members; finances. 
    Members of the beautification commission shall be reimbursed by the city for their actual expenses incurred in connection with the performance of their duties, and the city council may appropriate such funds as it deems appropriate to finance the activities of the commission. 
(Code 1975, § 2-155) 
Secs. 2-535-2-550. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CHARLESTON COLISEUM AND CONVENTION CENTER/MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM BOARD[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Retitled from "Civic Center-Auditorium Board" by Bill No. 7799 , adopted 11-19-2018 

Sec. 2-551. - Creation; term; vacancies; compensation. 
(a)  There is created a board to be known as "The Charleston Coliseum and Convention CenterMunicipal Auditorium Board." The board shall consist of 15 appointed members, two of whom shall be members of the city council, one of whom shall be a representative from the Racing Corporation of West Virginia dba Tri-State Racetrack & Gaming Center, one of whom shall be the President/CEO of the Charleston West Virginia Convention & Visitors Bureau, who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the council. The city manager shall also be a member of the board, ex officio. 
(b)  The councilmembers of the board shall serve for terms coextensive with their terms as members of the council; and the other appointed members shall serve for a term of four years each and until their respective successors are appointed and qualified, as follows: On or before June 22 of each year, three members shall be appointed; except that on or before June 22 in the year 1977 and every four years thereafter, only two members shall be appointed. Each member so appointed shall take office on June 22 of the year of his appointment. 
(c)  Vacancies other than by reason of expiration of term of office shall be filled for the unexpired term only. 
(d)  Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1975, § 2-156; Bill No. 7308, 12-17-2007; Bill. No. 7573, 5-5-2013; Bill No. 7799 , 11-19-2018) 
Sec. 2-552. - Officers; rules for transaction of business; meetings; records. 
    The Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center/Municipal Auditorium Board shall elect from its membership a chairman, secretary and such other officers as it determines to be necessary for the performance of its duties. The board shall adopt such rules as may be necessary for the transaction of its business; hold regular meetings, which shall be open to the public; and keep a record of its official proceedings, an official copy of which shall be filed in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1975, § 2-157; Bill No. 7799 , 11-19-2018) 
Sec. 2-553. - Powers and duties. 
    The Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center Municipal Auditorium Board shall have power, authority and duty to supervise, administer, operate and maintain the municipal civic, cultural and educational center of the city, located on Civic Center Drive, commonly called the "Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center," and the Municipal Auditorium, located on Virginia and Truslow streets, commonly called the "Auditorium"; to prepare, make, adopt, prescribe and promulgate instructions, procedures, rules and regulations appropriate for the management of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and the Auditorium; to provide for the safeguarding of and accountability for all funds derived from and in connection with the operation of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and Auditorium; and to determine, prescribe and collect all charges, fees and revenue of any kind due to the city for the use of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and Auditorium. However, any schedule of fees, rates or charges shall be first approved by the city council before being put into effect. The board shall not allow the property under its control to be used for or in connection with any program or purpose that is prohibited by law or resolution of council. The board shall have the authority to employ a manager and such other employees as are necessary properly to operate the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and Auditorium and, subject to approval of the council, to fix the compensation of such employees. 
(Code 1975, § 2-158; Bill No. 7799 , 11-19-2018) 
Sec. 2-554. - Finances. 
    All revenue derived from the use and operation of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and the Auditorium shall be paid into the city treasury, general fund; and all connected expenditures shall be requisitioned and accounted for in the same manner as other general fund expenditures. 
(Code 1975, § 2-159; Bill No. 7799 , 11-19-2018) 
Sec. 2-555. - Quarterly reports to city council. 
    The Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center/Municipal Auditorium Board shall make a written report to the city council of its operating expenses and finances, quarterly. 
(Code 1975, § 2-160; Bill No. 7799 , 11-19-2018) 
Sec. 2-556. - Schedule of rates, rentals and other charges for use of services and facilities. 
(a)  A true copy of the schedule of fees, rates and charges for the use of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and the Auditorium, as approved by the city council pursuant to the provisions of section 2-553, shall be maintained on file in the office of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center/Municipal Auditorium Board or the manager of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and Auditorium. 
(b)  All fees, rates and charges for the use of the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center and the Auditorium established or approved by the city council and in effect immediately prior to the effective date of this Code are continued in full force and effect until such time as new fees, rates and charges are determined, prescribed and approved pursuant to the provisions of section 2-553, as set forth in Chapter 82, Article 1, Section 82-4, Schedule of Rates and Rentals. 
(Code 1975, § 2-161; Bill No. 7799 , 11-19-2018) 
Secs. 2-557-2-580. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - KANAWHA VALLEY REGIONAL TRANSPORTATION AUTHORITY[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Urban Mass Transportation Authority Act, W. Va. Code § 8-27-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-621. - Created; statutory basis; name. 
    There is created and established, pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 27 (W. Va. Code § 8-27-1 et seq.), an urban mass transportation authority to be known as the "Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority." 
(Code 1975, § 2-162) 
State Law reference- Authority to create, W. Va. Code § 8-27-4. 
Sec. 2-622. - Initial participating governments. 
    The initial participating governments in the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority shall be the City of Charleston, a municipal corporation, and the county court of Kanawha County, West Virginia, a statutory corporate body. 
(Code 1975, § 2-163) 
Editor's note- As to the participation of the county court of Kanawha County, see orders entered by the court in its order book on Sept. 30, 1970, and on Oct. 5, 1970. 
Sec. 2-623. - Corporate status; powers and duties. 
    The Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority shall be a public corporation and is invested with all the powers authorized by and is directed to perform all of the duties imposed by W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 27 (W. Va. Code § 8-27-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1975, § 2-164) 
Sec. 2-624. - Number of board members; appointment of city and county members. 
    The board of the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority shall consist of not less than five and not more than 15 members. The initial board shall consist of five members, three of whom shall be appointed by the city council and two of whom shall be appointed by the county court for terms of three years each; except, however, the initial appointments by the city council shall be as follows: one member for a term of one year, one member for a term of two years, one member for a term of three years; and the initial appointments by the county court shall be for terms of one and two years respectively. 
(Code 1975, § 2-165) 
Editor's note- The initial appointments of city members were such that one vacancy occurs in October of each year. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 8-27-5. 
Sec. 2-625. - Number and distribution of votes of city members. 
    The three representatives of the city on the board of the members of the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority are entitled ten votes, which votes are to be divided equally among the three members with each having 3 1/3 votes. If, however, there are less than three members of the city appointed or present at any meeting of the authority, all of the ten votes may be cast by the member present; or in case of two members present, each may cast five votes. 
(Code 1975, § 2-165.1) 
Sec. 2-626. - Board membership open to representatives of other regional governmental bodies. 
    Membership on the board of the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority shall be open to representatives of other regional governmental bodies who may later so desire, by enacting an appropriate ordinance or order as prescribed by W. Va. Code § 8-27-4, in which event the board created in this division shall increase the membership of the board to such number as it may deem necessary, not to exceed 15. The number of members representing each participating government shall be as agreed upon by the governing bodies of the participating governments. 
(Code 1975, § 2-166) 
Sec. 2-627. - Availability to authority of services of planning commission. 
    The city will make available to the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority the services of the municipal planning commission upon request. 
(Code 1975, § 2-167) 
Sec. 2-628. - City not obligated financially except by approval of city council. 
    The city shall not obligate itself to participate financially with the Kanawha Valley Regional Transportation Authority except with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-168) 
Secs. 2-629-2-650. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - MUNICIPAL BUILDING COMMISSION[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal building commissions, W. Va. Code § 8-33-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-651. - Created. 
    There is created, pursuant to W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 33 (W. Va. Code § 8-33-1 et seq.), a municipal building commission to be known as the Charleston Building Commission, which shall be a public corporation having perpetual existence and, except as hereinafter expressly limited, shall have all of the power and authority provided in W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 33 (W. Va. Code § 8-33-1 et seq.), for such a commission. 
(Code 1975, § 2-178) 
State Law reference- Authority to create, W. Va. Code § 8-33-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-652. - Membership; terms; compensation. 
(a)  All property, powers and duties and the management and control of the municipal building commission shall be vested in a board consisting of representatives, to be known as commissioners, appointed by the city council. Such board shall consist of five members, each to be appointed for a term of five years except for the initial appointments, which shall be made as follows: 
(1)  The first commissioner appointed shall serve a term of one year from the date this section becomes law. 
(2)  The second commissioner appointed shall serve a term of two years from the date this section becomes law. 
(3)  The third commissioner appointed shall serve a term of three years from the date this section becomes law. 
(4)  The fourth commissioner appointed shall serve a term of four years from the date this section becomes law. 
(5)  The fifth commissioner appointed shall serve a term of five years from the date this section becomes law. 
(b)  As the term of each such initial appointee expires, the successor to fill the vacancy created by such expired term shall be appointed for a term of five years. If any commissioner appointed under this section fails or refuses to qualify within 20 days of appointment or if the position of any commissioner becomes vacant for any reason prior to the expiration of his term of office, a successor shall be appointed by the city council to complete the unexpired portion of such term. 
(c)  No more than three of the five commissioners shall be from the same political party; and no member of the board of commissioners shall hold any office (other than the office of notary public) or employment under the United States, the state, any county or political subdivision, or any political party. Each commissioner at the time of his appointment shall be a resident of the city. No commissioner shall receive any compensation for his services as such, but each member shall be reimbursed by the commission for any reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of his duties as a member of the board. 
(Code 1975, § 2-179) 
Sec. 2-653. - Powers and authority. 
    Subject to the procedures and limitations set forth in this division, the municipal building commission shall have plenary power and authority to: 
(1)  Sue and be sued. 
(2)  Contract and be contracted with. 
(3)  Adopt, use and alter a common seal. 
(4)  Make and adopt all necessary, appropriate and lawful bylaws and rules and regulations pertaining to its affairs. 
(5)  Elect such officers, appoint such committees and agents, and employ and fix the compensation of such employees and contractors as may be necessary for the conduct of the affairs and operations of the commission. 
(6)  Acquire, purchase, own and hold any property, real or personal, and acquire, construct, equip, maintain and operate public buildings, structures, projects and appurtenant facilities, of any type for which the city council is permitted by law to expend public funds. 
(7)  Apply for, receive and use grants-in-aid, donations and contributions from any source, including but not limited to the United States or any of its departments or agencies, and accept and use bequests, devises, gifts and donations from any source whatsoever. 
(8)  Sell, encumber or dispose of any property, real or personal. 
(9)  Issue negotiable bonds, notes, debentures or other evidences of indebtedness and provide for the rights of the holders; incur any proper indebtedness; and issue any obligations and give any security which it may deem necessary or advisable in connection with exercising powers as provided in this division. 
(10)  Raise funds by the issuance of revenue bonds in the manner provided by the applicable provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 16 (W. Va. Code § 8-16-1 et seq.), without regard, to the extent provided in W. Va. Code § 8-33-5, to the limitations specified in W. Va. Code § 8-33-5, it being hereby expressly provided that for the purpose of the issuance and sale of revenue bonds, such commission is a governing body as that term is used in W. Va. Code § 8-33-5 only. 
(11)  Exercise the power of eminent domain in the manner provided in W. Va. Code ch. 54 (W. Va. Code § 54-1-1 et seq.) for business corporations, for the purposes set forth in subsection (6) of this section, which purposes are declared to be public purposes for which private property may be taken or damaged. 
(12)  Lease its property or any part of its property, for public purposes, to such persons and upon such terms as the commission deems proper; but when any municipality or county commission is a lessee under any such lease, such lease must contain a provision granting to such municipality or county commission the option to terminate such lease during any fiscal year covered by the lease. 
(13)  Do all things reasonable and necessary to carry out the powers specified in this section. 
(Code 1975, § 2-180) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 8-33-4. 
Sec. 2-654. - Financial obligation. 
    No indebtedness of any nature of the municipal building commission shall constitute an indebtedness of the city or a charge against any property of the city. No indebtedness or obligation incurred by the commission shall give any right against any member of the governing body of the city or against any member of the board of the commission. The rights of creditors of the commission shall be solely against the commission as a corporate body and shall be satisfied only out of property held in its corporate capacity. 
(Code 1975, § 2-181) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 8-33-5. 
Secs. 2-655-2-680. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - WAYFINDING COMMISSION
