Secs. 22-44-22-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMISSION 

Sec. 22-61. - Creation; power and duties. 
(a)  In the exercise of the general powers of the city, pursuant to W. Va. Code § 8-12-5 and W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 16 (W. Va. Code § 8-16-1 et seq.), there is created a cemetery park commission to be known as The Spring Hill Cemetery Park Commission. 
(b)  The commission shall have power, authority and duty as set forth herein in relation to the grounds purchased by the city and more particularly described in all deeds of conveyance to the city and of record in the office of the clerk of the county commission and any other grounds which have been appropriated by the city for the purpose of a cemetery, and any other adjacent land which may be purchased or acquired by the city for cemetery purposes. Except where reference to separate cemetery grounds is necessary for specific provisions, the foregoing cemetery grounds and all structures and improvements are collectively referred to for purposes of this division as the cemetery or as Spring Hill Cemetery Park. 
(c)  The commission shall have the plenary power and authority to acquire by gift, grant, purchase, condemnation or otherwise and thereafter hold all necessary lands, rights, easements, rights-of-way, franchises and other property for the Spring Hill Cemetery Park; however, the commission's right of condemnation shall not extend beyond the current perimeter boundaries of the Spring Hill Cemetery. 
(d)  The commission shall have the power, authority, and duty to establish reasonable and lawful rules and regulations for the cemetery related to: 
(1)  Interments; 
(2)  conduct within the cemetery, including, but not limited to, access, visitation, funerals, assemblages, tours, traffic, parking, and protocols for respecting the deceased; 
(3)  Mausoleums, columbariums, and other structures of entombment; 
(4)  Burial lots; 
(5)  Monuments, markers, cenotaphs, memorializations, and decorations; 
(6)  Gardens, lawns and plantings; 
(7)  Creation, administration, investment, review and accounting of and for endowments and trust funds and the expenditure thereof. 
A copy of the cemetery rules and regulations promulgated by the commission shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and may, upon request, be provided to anyone purchasing a right of interment. 
(e)  The commission shall have the power, authority, and duty to plan for the orderly development of the cemetery; to identify, plat, denote, delineate and name distinct sections, lots, roadways and other geographical features; to establish procedures for submission and review of plans and specifications for any construction or installation within the cemetery; to reserve or designate areas within the cemetery as places for assemblage, passive spaces, natural habitat, or for other beneficial uses related to the character and purpose of the cemetery; and to recommend to the mayor, city manager, superintendent and/or city council such development, programs or projects as would, in the opinion of the commission, improve the beauty, utility and general welfare of the cemetery. 
(f)  The commission shall have the power, authority, and duty to receive complaints or petitions related to interests in rights of interment, descent or division, errors of documentation or description, application or enforcement of any rule or regulation promulgated by the commission, and petitions for variances or exceptions to any rule or regulation promulgated by the commission, and to make inquiry and investigations thereof. The commission shall be the arbiter of any such complaints or petitions. The commission may establish reasonable rules and procedures to secure fair and timely determinations of every such complaint or petition, and, if requested or when otherwise necessary and practical to do so, shall timely issue written decisions, copies of which shall be provided to all interested parties, the city manager and filed with the city clerk. Any decision of the commission may be appealed by filing a written notice of appeal to the city manager within 30 days of transmission of the commission's decision to the complaining party or parties. 
(Bill No. 7540, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 22-62. - Membership; terms; compensation. 
(a)  All powers and duties in the management and control of the commission shall be vested in a board consisting of directors appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. Such board shall consist of nine appointed members, two of whom shall be members of city council. The councilmembers of the board shall serve for a term coextensive with their terms as members of the council; and the other members of the board shall each be appointed for a term of six years and until their respective successors are appointed and qualified, except for the initial appointments, which shall be made as follows: 
(1)  The first director appointed shall serve a term of nine years commencing on _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(2)  The second director appointed shall serve a term of eight years commencing on _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(3)  The third director appointed shall serve a term of seven years commencing on _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(4)  The fourth director appointed shall serve a term of six years commencing on _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(5)  The fifth director appointed shall serve a term of five years commencing on _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(6)  The sixth director appointed shall serve a term of four years commencing on _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(7)  The seventh director appointed shall serve a term of two years commencing on __ _____/_____/_____, 1998. 
(b)  As the term of each initial board appointee, other than the councilmembers, expires, the successor to fill the vacancy created by such expired term shall be appointed for a term of six years. 
(c)  If the position of any director becomes vacant for any reason prior to the expiration of his term of office, a successor shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council to complete the unexpired portion of such term. 
(d)  The directors shall be appointed without regard to political affiliation, and preference shall be given to lineal descendants or immediate family relatives of someone interred at the cemetery. No director shall receive any compensation for his service as such, but each director shall be reimbursed by the commission for any reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of his duties as a member of the board. No director may be an employee of the city; and no director may benefit financially in any way, directly or indirectly, from the operation of the commission or its board of directors. 
(Bill No. 7540, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 22-63. - Officers; rules for transaction of business; meetings; records. 
    The commission board shall elect from its membership a chairman, secretary and such other officers as it determines to be necessary for the performance of its duties. The board may adopt such rules as may be necessary for the transaction of its business, hold regular meetings, and shall keep a record of its official proceedings, a copy of which shall be filed in the city clerk's office. 
(Bill No. 7540, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 22-64. - Operations and management. 
    The cemetery shall be operated as a city department under the direction of a Superintendent, subject to such funding and staffing levels as the city council may designate and allocate within its general fund budget, who shall be appointed by the city manager with the advice and consent of the commission, and who shall report to the city manager. The cemetery shall be operated according to the administrative rules, regulations, and policies generally applicable to city departments. In addition to any other duties or responsibilities set forth herein or attendant to the position as the administrative department head, the superintendent shall be charged with executing and enforcing the reasonable rules and regulations promulgated by the commission as provided herein, shall attend and participate in the meetings of the commission as a non-voting member, and shall provide such information and reports as the commission may request and require for the fulfillment of its duties. 
(Bill No. 7540, 10-1-2012) 
Chapter 26 - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Solicitation of Charitable Funds Act, W. Va. Code § 29-19-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Board of solicitation review. 
(a)  There is created a nonpartisan board of solicitation review, consisting of three members. The members will consist of three residents of the city, who shall be appointed by the mayor, each for a term of four years and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  The mayor shall appoint one of the three members as chairman of the board. The appointed members of the board shall serve without salary. The board shall have power to prescribe rules and regulations for the carrying out of the purposes expressed in this chapter. The board shall meet in regular session at least once a month, at a time to be fixed by the board, and shall meet more often if necessary to perform the duties imposed on the board by this article. The director shall attend all meetings of the board. 
(Code 1975, § 10-10) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-511 et seq. 
Sec. 26-2. - Unauthorized, unrestricted, unregulated begging or solicitation prohibited. 
(a)  The unauthorized, unrestricted and unregulated public begging or solicitation in the city of money, subscriptions or contributions for any charitable, educational or benevolent purposes, upon the streets, in public places, in buildings and from house to house, or by the use of the telephone or otherwise, is contrary to the promotion of economic integrity, is detrimental to the morals, comfort and welfare of the inhabitants of the city, is unlawful and is forbidden; but nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent or forbid any pastor, priest, rabbi, rector or minister of the gospel, or the governing body of any church from soliciting funds within their membership exclusively for religious and church purposes. 
(b)  The offering for sale of tickets for any dance, show or other performance represented as being for the benefit of a charitable purpose shall be deemed to be the solicitation of money within the prohibition of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 10-11) 
Secs. 26-3-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 

Sec. 26-31. - Application for permit. 
    Any person desiring to solicit money, subscriptions or contributions for any charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purposes as set forth in this article shall file with the director an application, on a form approved by the director, and shall answer, under oath, all of the questions contained in the form and furnish to the director all such information with reference to the public solicitation of funds as may be of assistance to the director in determining whether permission shall be given to such person for the purpose of soliciting funds for such purposes, and the failure or refusal to file the application and furnish the information shall constitute sufficient grounds for the director to decline the application of the applicant for permission to solicit funds for the purposes set forth in this article. In no instance may a permit be issued to a professional solicitor or its agents, servants or employees unless a contract or written agreement between the professional fundraiser and its client has been previously filed with the director. The director may impose such other conditions and terms precedent to the issuance of the permit provided for as may be deemed reasonable. 
(Code 1975, § 10-12) 
Sec. 26-32. - Limitations on amount of payments to professional solicitors for solicitation activities. 
    No charitable, religious, educational or benevolent organization shall pay to a professional solicitor or its agents, servants or employees in the aggregate a total amount in excess of 15 percent (including reimbursements for expenses incurred) of the total money, pledges and other property raised or received by reason of any solicitation activities. For the purposes of this section, the total money, funds, pledges or other property raised or received shall not include the actual cost to charitable, religious, educational or benevolent organizations or professional solicitors of goods sold or service provided to the public in connection with the soliciting of contributions. If the contract, or written statement of the nature of the arrangement to prevail in the absence of a contract between a professional solicitor and a charitable, religious, educational or benevolent organization does not provide for compensation on a percentage basis, the director shall examine the contract to ascertain whether the compensation to be paid in such circumstances is likely to exceed 15 percent of the total money, pledges or other property raised or received as a result of the contract or arrangements; if the reasonable probabilities are that compensation will exceed 15 percent of the total money, pledges or other property, the director shall not issue a permit as provided in section 26-33. 
(Code 1975, § 10-13) 
Sec. 26-33. - Investigation of permit application; issuance or denial of permit; appeals. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director to investigate all applications of persons desiring to solicit funds for charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purposes; and if the director, after such investigation, is satisfied that the purpose of such solicitation is a bona fide charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purpose, that the applicant for the permit will solicit in good faith and in the manner authorized for such bona fide charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purposes and that a proper proportion of the money subscribed or contributed will be used for the purpose for which the subscription or contribution is made, it shall be the duty of the director to issue to such applicant a card giving the name of the person so authorized to solicit, the purpose for which the funds are being solicited, the time within which solicitations of money, contributions or subscriptions are permitted, the manner in which such solicitation is authorized and whether the person soliciting funds is being paid for his services as such solicitor. It shall not be necessary for each solicitor to apply to the director where more than one person is soliciting for the same purpose, but a general application for such persons may be made by any one of them, and cards for all such solicitors may be issued upon one application. If the director, after investigation of any application for a permit to solicit funds, decides that such permit should not be issued, the director shall decline to issue such permit; and the person whose application has been declined by the director shall have the right of appeal to the board of solicitation review. The board shall hear and determine the application and appeal at any open meeting, after notice to the applicant and appellant; and the decision of a majority of the members of the board, after such hearing, shall be binding on all of the parties. 
(b)  An appeal from the decision of the board may be taken before the city council, which shall, in such instances, have the power to sustain or reverse the decision of the board; but no appeal to the city council shall be recognized as such until after notice of such appeal has been published in at least one newspaper in the city for ten consecutive days. At the time of such hearing, the director shall be present to furnish the council with full information in support of the board's decision. 
(Code 1975, § 10-14) 
Sec. 26-34. - Card or certificate from director required. 
    Any person conducting a campaign or soliciting money, subscriptions or contributions for any charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purposes upon the streets, in public places, in buildings and from house to house, or by the use of the telephone, or otherwise in the city shall have and exhibit at all times when soliciting such funds a card or certificate from the director. The card shall authorize such person to solicit money, subscriptions or contributions for such purposes, in the manner and at the time when such solicitation of funds is made. Any person soliciting funds, subscriptions or contributions without such permit or certificate duly issued by the director or in any manner not authorized by the director shall be guilty of an offense against this section. 
(Code 1975, § 10-15) 
Sec. 26-35. - Suspension or cancellation of permit; jurisdiction of municipal court to issue subpoenas duces tecum. 
    In the event of violation of the conditions, limitations or restrictions imposed in the granting of any permit provided for in this article, or in the event of the misapplication of any funds collected thereunder, the director may suspend the effectiveness of the permit pending a hearing before the board as to whether or not any condition, limitation or restriction imposed by the director in the granting of such permit has been violated. Such suspension of the permit shall be in effect only until the hearing before the board, upon reasonable notice, at which hearing the holder of the permit may appear before the board, in person or by counsel, and may produce evidence. The board is authorized to hear testimony and swear witnesses, and the municipal court or the municipal judge is hereby authorized to issue subpoenas duces tecum upon application and proper showing being made by the board, such subpoenas to be served by any police officer of the city. If upon the hearing the board shall determine that this chapter has been violated, or any condition, limitation or restriction imposed in any permit has been violated, the board may cancel the permit or may suspend its effectiveness for such time as the board may deem advisable. The board shall make a written finding of the facts, based upon the testimony heard by it; and its finding as to the facts shall be conclusive. 
(Code 1975, § 10-16) 
Sec. 26-36. - Fees and bonds. 
(a)  Any application for permission to solicit funds shall be accompanied by a fee of $10.00. Once permission to solicit is obtained, any person or organization other than a professional solicitor shall post a cash bond of $250.00. Professional solicitors shall post a cash bond of $1,000.00 or ten percent of the total money, pledges and other property to be raised or received by reason of solicitation activities, whichever is less, but in no event less than $250.00. Such cash bond shall be refunded to the person or organization; provided, that such person or organization shall, within 45 days after the completion of the fundraising campaign, notify the director with a financial report stressing the amount raised, expenses of the campaign and projected use of the proceeds raised. 
(b)  Where multiple fundraising campaigns are conducted simultaneously by the same person or organization, the director may, in his discretion, not require a separate cash bond to be posted for each campaign. In no event, however, may all cash bond money posted by any person or organization be returned until all fundraising campaigns of that person or organization have been completed and the director has been so notified with a proper financial report. 
(Code 1975, § 10-17) 
Chapter 30 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; planning, ch. 90; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 102; subdivision regulations, ch. 106; utilities, ch. 118; zoning, app. B. 
State Law reference- West Virginia Community Improvement Act, W. Va. Code § 16-13B-1 et seq.; Urban Renewal Authority Law, W. Va. Code § 16-18-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Shelton-Sentz Neighborhood Redevelopment Select Committee. 
    There is appointed a select committee of council to be known as the "Shelton-Sentz Neighborhood Redevelopment Select Committee." Such committee shall be composed of the mayor of the city and the members from time to time of the finance committee of the council. A majority of the members of the committee shall constitute a quorum, and the committee may meet by the majority vote of the members in attendance at any meeting, a quorum being present. The mayor shall be the chairman of the committee, and the committee shall designate one of its members, or a member of the administrative staff, to keep a record of its proceedings. The committee shall make its own rules as to the calling of meetings and notices of and the conduct of meetings. There is vested in the committee all power and authority of the city council, with respect to the matters relating to the Shelton-Sentz project, which are lawfully delegable to such a committee under the laws of the state and the city; however, the council reserves the right to modify or rescind any action taken by the committee and to alter the powers, authorities and membership of the committee, or abolish the committee to the extent the council may do so without impairing any rights which have become vested in any person by virtue of action taken by the committee. 
(Code 1975, § 2-13.1) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-511 et seq. 
Secs. 30-2-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - URBAN RENEWAL AUTHORITY[2] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Urban Renewal Authority Law, W. Va. Code § 16-18-1 et seq. 

Secs. 30-31-30-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NEIGHBORHOOD REHABILITATION PROGRAM 

Sec. 30-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Eligible dwelling means real estate upon which there is located a structure designed primarily for residential housing and consisting of dwelling units for not more than four families; provided, that all occupancy shall be limited to persons and families who would qualify as eligible residents. 
    Eligible resident means a person or family residing in an eligible dwelling, owned by such person or family, situated within the corporate limits of the city, irrespective of race, creed, national origin or sex, with respect to whom it is determined by the city council that: 
(1)  Such person or family, because of financial conditions, age, infirmity, family size or other reasons, is unable to obtain, on suitable terms and conditions, loans or other credit necessary for the rehabilitation of such eligible dwelling, and hence requires the assistance as provided in this article; 
(2)  Such rehabilitation is necessary to place such eligible dwelling in a safe, sanitary and decent condition; and 
(3)  The assistance as authorized in this article shall make financing available to such person or family, or enable such person or family to obtain such financing, on terms and conditions substantially more favorable to such person or family than would otherwise be available. 
    Rehabilitation means a specific work of improvement within the city undertaken primarily to remodel, repair or rehabilitate an eligible dwelling occupied by an eligible resident as his principal residence. 
(Code 1975, § 5-71) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-62. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  The city council finds and declares that there has been for a number of years a clear trend for younger and more affluent persons and families residing in the city to move their residences from the inner urban areas of the city to newer suburban areas; that as a result, a disproportionate number of homeowners remaining in such inner urban areas are older, less affluent and otherwise less able to afford the expense of the remodeling, repairing and rehabilitating of their residences necessary to maintain such residences in a sanitary, safe and decent condition; that because of their lack of acceptable loan collateral, the age of their residences and the location and age of the neighborhoods in which their residences are located, many of such homeowners have not been able to borrow funds necessary to effect such remodeling, repair and rehabilitation; and that some homeowners who have been able to borrow funds for such purposes have been able to do so only upon rates of interest and upon other terms and conditions which are particularly onerous to such homeowners. 
(b)  The city council further finds and declares that the assistance authorized by this article will provide and will encourage private lenders to provide to such homeowners, more readily and at rates of interest and upon other terms and conditions significantly more favorable to such homeowners, the loans necessary to finance the cost of such remodeling, repair and rehabilitation. 
(c)  The city council further finds and declares that it is manifestly in the public interest to foster, in the populous inner urban areas of this city, the pride, self-respect and esteem incident to home ownership and to encourage and assist in the maintenance of residences situated in such areas in a safe, decent and sanitary condition; that without the assistance authorized in this article, there will be continued deterioration of such inner urban areas with the resultant proliferation of urban decay and slums, higher crime rates and general decline in civic pride, public spirit and the quality of life, with all of the public cost, direct and indirect, attendant thereon; and that accordingly by providing such assistance the city will be acting in all respects for the benefit of its citizens and shall thereby serve a public purpose in improving and otherwise promoting their health, welfare and prosperity. 
(Code 1975, § 5-70) 
Sec. 30-63. - Neighborhood rehabilitation fund; guaranteed loans. 
(a)  There is established a special fund of moneys to be made available by appropriation, grant, contribution, loan or otherwise, to be known as the "Neighborhood Rehabilitation Fund of the City of Charleston." Such neighborhood rehabilitation fund shall be administered and accounted for as a special purpose account, separate and distinct from any other moneys or funds owned by the city. 
(b)  The city council shall from time to time, by resolution, establish criteria which shall govern the determination of persons and families who qualify as eligible residents. 
(c)  The purpose of such neighborhood rehabilitation fund shall be to provide funds for the making of loans, or to guarantee the repayment of loans made by private lenders, to eligible residents of the city, the proceeds of which loans are to be used exclusively for rehabilitation. 
(d)  Such loans shall be made or guaranteed only upon determination by the city council, or by the rehabilitation fund commission, that the borrowers are eligible residents; that the proceeds of the loan shall be used for rehabilitation; and that loans to such eligible borrowers for rehabilitation are not otherwise available upon reasonable equivalent terms and conditions. 
(e)  No loan shall be made or guaranteed by the city except in accordance with a written agreement between such city, the eligible resident and, in the case of a guaranteed loan, the lender making such loan, which agreement shall provide without limitation that: 
(1)  The proceeds of such loan shall be used exclusively for rehabilitation. 
(2)  The loan shall be in such principal amount, repayable in such number of consecutive and substantially equal monthly installments, at such annual rate of interest and shall be secured in such manner as specified in such agreement. 
(3)  In the case of a guaranteed loan, the city shall, at its option and in accordance with predefined criteria, repay, from the neighborhood rehabilitation fund established in accordance with this article, any installment or installments of such loan as shall be in default. If the city chooses not to make such repayment, the lender may foreclose on the security for the loan and the city shall pay to such lender, from the neighborhood rehabilitation fund, the amount, if any, by which the unpaid balance of the loan, including accrued interest, exceeds the proceeds of such foreclosure. 
(4)  If the city incurs an obligation on a guaranteed loan under the provisions of subsection (e)(3) of this section, the city shall be entitled, at its option, to realize on any and all security for such loan; provided; that the right of the city to realize on such security with respect to a guaranteed loan shall be subordinate and secondary to the right of the lender as to such security, to the extent of the unpaid balance of such loan. If the city incurs an obligation on a guaranteed loan under the provisions of subsection (e)(3) of this section, the city shall be subrogated to the right of the lender against the eligible resident to the extent of all payments made by the city to the lender with respect to such loan. 
(f)  Nothing contained in this article shall be so construed as to authorize the city to make any contract or incur any obligation or liability of any kind or nature, except such as shall be discharged or payable solely from the funds on deposit in such neighborhood rehabilitation fund. 
(Code 1975, § 5-72) 
Sec. 30-64. - Rehabilitation fund commission. 
    There is created a commission to be known as the "Charleston Rehabilitation Fund Commission," which shall be comprised of three members, no more than two members of the same political party, who shall be appointed by and serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To determine the eligibility of applicants for loans from or to be guaranteed by the neighborhood rehabilitation fund in accordance with criteria as established from time to time by the council by resolution, and to ensure that the proceeds of such loans are used for rehabilitation, and that loans to such eligible residents for rehabilitation are not otherwise available upon reasonably equivalent terms and conditions. 
(2)  At the request of eligible residents, to cause inspections to be made of their residences, to make recommendations concerning rehabilitation and to provide all manner of technical services and assistance in the planning, processing and design of needed rehabilitation. 
(3)  To cause to be prepared all forms of loan agreements, promissory notes, deeds of trust and other agreements and instruments as such commission shall deem necessary for the implementation of such program. 
(4)  To negotiate with banks, savings and loan associations and other lending institutions in the city and to obtain commitments from one or more of such institutions to provide loans to residents eligible to participate in such program, such loans to be guaranteed by the neighborhood rehabilitation fund. 
(5)  In general, to administer and coordinate the making and guaranteeing of loans from the neighborhood rehabilitation fund and to have such additional incidental powers and duties, including the hiring of consultants, as shall be necessary for the furtherance of the purposes of the neighborhood rehabilitation fund. 
(6)  To adopt rules and regulations for its government, to study housing problems existing in the city with reference to the need for and feasibility of rehabilitation loans and to advise city council as to such problems and the recommendations of the commission. 
(Code 1975, § 5-73) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-511 et seq. 
Chapter 34 - CONSUMER PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- West Virginia Consumer Protection and Credit Act, W. Va. Code § 46A-1-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSUMER PROTECTION DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 34-31. - Created. 
    There is created a department of consumer protection. 
(Code 1975, § 10-1) 
Sec. 34-32. - City policy declared; purpose of article. 
    It is declared to be the public policy of the city and the purpose of this chapter is to protect and promote the public safety, health and welfare; to investigate and inquire into all matters related to consumer protection which concern this city or its inhabitants; and to prevent injury or annoyance to consumers from anything dangerous, offensive or unwholesome. The city declares that government advances the interest of consumers by facilitating the proper functioning of the free enterprise market economy through educating and informing the consumer to ensure rational consumer choice in the market place and protecting the consumer from the sale of goods and services through the use of deceptive methods, acts or practices which are inimical to the general welfare of the consumer. 
(Code 1975, § 10-2) 
Sec. 34-33. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consumer means any individual who seeks or acquires by purchase or lease any goods, services or money for credit for family, personal or household purposes. The term also means any individual who is subject to public solicitation of money, subscriptions or contributions for charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purposes. 
    Department means the department of consumer protection. 
    Director means the director of the department of consumer protection. 
(Code 1975, § 10-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-34. - Director and department personnel. 
    The director shall be appointed by the mayor to serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. Within the limits of funds available for such purpose, other necessary personnel may be employed. All such personnel shall perform their respective duties under the supervision and direction of the director. 
(Code 1975, § 10-4) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-131 et seq. 
Sec. 34-35. - Administration of article. 
    The director shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article. Every power granted or duty imposed upon the director under this article may be exercised and performed in the name of the director by any employee of the department, subject to such conditions and limitations as the director may prescribe. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 34-36. - Powers and duties of director. 
    The director shall have the following powers and it shall be his duty to: 
(1)  Recommend and propose the enactment of such ordinances as are necessary to protect and promote the interests of consumers. 
(2)  Assist, advise and cooperate with federal, state and local agencies and officials to protect and promote the interests of consumers. 
(3)  Study, investigate, conduct, research and analyze matters affecting the interests of consumers. 
(4)  Propose and assist in the creation and development of consumer education programs. 
(5)  Promote ethical standards of conduct for businesses and consumers, and undertake activities to encourage public responsibility in the production, promotion, sale and lease of consumer goods and services. 
(6)  Advise the mayor and city council on all matters affecting the interests of consumers. 
(7)  Authorize, regulate, restrict and control public begging or soliciting of money, subscriptions or contributions for any charitable, religious, educational or benevolent purpose. 
(8)  Issue placards or notices for the use of all persons in giving notice to the public that no contributions are made for the purposes of chapter 26 except to solicitors authorized by the director. 
(9)  Exercise and perform such other functions, powers and duties as may be deemed appropriate to protect and promote the interests of consumers as directed by the mayor or the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 10-6) 
Sec. 34-37. - Reception of complaints by director. 
    It shall be the duty of the director to receive complaints from consumers concerning: 
(1)  Unfair methods of competition and unfair or deceptive acts or practices undertaken by any person in the conduct of any trade or commerce. 
(2)  The production, distribution, sale or lease of any goods and services undertaken by any person which may endanger the public health, safety or welfare. 
(3)  Other matters consistent with the purposes of this article, whenever appropriate. 
(Code 1975, § 10-7) 
Sec. 34-38. - Notice of complaint; referrals; patterns of complaint. 
(a)  Upon receipt of any complaint in writing pursuant to section 34-37, the director shall investigate the complaint; and if it is found to be valid, he may notify the person against whom the complaint is made of the nature of the complaint and may request appropriate relief for the consumer. 
(b)  If the director receives a complaint or receives information from any source indicating a probable violation of any law or rule or order of any regulatory agency of the federal, state, county or city government, or if a pattern of complaints from consumers develops, the director shall transmit any complaints he considers to be valid to any appropriate law enforcement or regulatory agency and any evidence or information he may have concerning such probable violation or pattern of complaints. 
(Code 1975, § 10-8) 
Sec. 34-39. - Dissemination of information. 
    The director may disseminate to the public in such form and manner as he deems most appropriate information, statistics and other data concerning the following: 
(1)  Functions, duties, powers and activities of the department and of those agencies which provide relief from commercial and trade practices which are inimical to the interest of the consumer. 
(2)  Commercial and trade practices which are detrimental to consumers. 
(3)  Goods and services which are unsafe, unhealthful or inimical to the general welfare of consumers. 
(4)  General economic conditions. 
(5)  Test results, analyses and studies of consumer products and services in the possession of local, state and federal agencies. 
(6)  Consumer education which the director may develop on his own initiative or obtain from other sources. 
(Code 1975, § 10-9) 
Chapter 38 - COURTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 66; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; traffic ordinance, ch. 114. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal judge, § 44 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, W. Va. Code § 8-10-2 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-31. - Court established, to be held by municipal judge. 
    There shall be in the city a court, which shall be called the municipal court, to be held by the municipal judge of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 16-1) 
Sec. 38-32. - Jurisdiction, powers and duties relating to violations of the traffic ordinance. 
    The municipal court shall have jurisdiction of all offenses under the traffic ordinance, chapter 114, and the municipal judge shall have the power to assess and collect fines and costs from any person who fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of the traffic ordinance or with the rules and regulations of the chief of police made in conformity with such ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 16-2) 
Sec. 38-33. - Sessions. 
    There shall be a daily session of the municipal court, commencing at an hour to be determined by the municipal judge, on each day of the week, except Saturdays, Sundays and holidays; provided, that the municipal judge may, in his discretion and from time to time, by proper order, provide for additional sessions of court at such hour as he may determine. 
(Code 1975, § 16-3) 
Sec. 38-34. - Duties of clerk. 
    The duties and requirements of the municipal court clerk, except as otherwise provided, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Trial docket. He shall produce each day at the opening of the court a docket in which shall be entered all cases set for trial on that day. The cases shall be numbered progressively on the docket, the papers in each case numbered to correspond. The title of every case entertained by the municipal judge shall be entered upon the docket, setting forth the name of the defendant, the charge against him, the name of the officer arresting him, and the disposition made by the municipal judge of the case, and the disposition made by him of the defendant, whether discharged or imprisoned, and if the latter, the term of imprisonment, and whether admitted to bail or committed to answer the indictment. In each case continuances, if any may be granted, shall be noted, also the amount of all fines imposed, all costs thereto attached, and to whom payable. The docket shall be indexed in the names of the defendants. 
(2)  Fines, costs, process and oaths. He shall tax all costs in the municipal court and make out all executions for fines, penalties and costs imposed by the municipal judge, make out and issue all processes of the court and sign them as clerk, and administer oaths. 
(3)  Reports of fines for traffic violations. He shall, within five days after the close of each preceding calendar month, make a report in writing to the mayor and city council of the amount of fines and costs assessed and collected by the court for traffic violations during such calendar month. 
(Code 1975, § 16-4) 
Sec. 38-35. - Deputy clerks. 
    The mayor may appoint, within the limit of funds available, one or more deputy municipal court clerks, who shall have, in addition to such other duties as may be assigned to them by the municipal court clerk or the municipal judge, the authority to administer oaths to complainants, to issue arrest warrants for all violations of this Code and other municipal ordinances, and to issue commitments to jail and accept bonds and sureties. In the absence of the municipal judge, the mayor, municipal court clerk or deputy municipal court clerk may issue warrants for arrests, administer oaths, issue commitments, and accept and approve sureties and bonds. The term "absence" is defined to mean when the municipal judge is not physically in the building. 
(Code 1975, § 16-5) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-131 et seq. 
Sec. 38-36. - Bailiff. 
    The chief of police shall, by roster or otherwise, designate a police officer to attend all sessions of the municipal court as bailiff. The bailiff shall preserve order in the courtroom and in its immediate vicinity and shall execute all orders given him by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1975, § 16-6) 
Sec. 38-37. - Style of prosecutions; arrest of offenders; summoning witnesses. 
    All prosecutions, actions and proceedings for the violation of the ordinances of the city or any of them, or any section or part, shall be entitled "The City of Charleston against ___________," (the person violating the ordinance). In all prosecutions in cases of arrest for an offense committed in the presence of a police officer, after the offender shall have been brought before the municipal judge, the officer making the arrest shall reduce or have reduced to writing the charge alleged against such person and also state that such arrest was made for an offense committed in his presence, which writing shall be subscribed and sworn to by such officer; and it shall not be deemed effective for want of form if it shows substantially an offense against the ordinances of the city. In all prosecutions in cases in which a person charged with a breach of any of the ordinances of the city has not been arrested in the act of committing the offense, a warrant for the arrest of the person charged shall not be issued except upon probable cause, nor until a complaint in writing, supported by an affidavit describing particularly the person to be arrested, shall have been duly made; and in the same warrant the municipal judge may require the officer to whom it is directed to summon such witnesses as are named to appear and give evidence on the examination of such party. 
(Code 1975, § 16-7) 
Sec. 38-38. - Issuance and service of process. 
    All warrants, subpoenas, executions or other processes issued by the municipal judge shall run in the name of the city, and each warrant, subpoena, execution or process shall be directed to any police officer of the city whose duty it shall be to execute it, either by reading it to the person named, or by delivering him a copy, or by leaving a copy of it at his usual place of abode, or in any other manner provided by law. The officer shall make proper return. 
(Code 1975, § 16-8) 
Sec. 38-39. - Default judgments. 
    When a defendant, duly summoned, fails to appear at the time the proceeding is set for trial, the municipal judge shall declare the defendant's bond or cash deposit forfeited and enter any judgment as may be warranted by the law and the facts of the case. 
(Code 1975, § 16-9) 
Sec. 38-40. - Bail bond or cash deposit. 
    Whenever any person is arrested for any violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city or for any offense of which the municipal judge has jurisdiction, it shall be lawful for the municipal judge, city clerk, municipal court clerk, mayor, chief of police and the desk sergeant or person in charge of police headquarters, and the county jailer to admit such person to bail upon the execution of a bond to the city in such an amount as in the discretion of the officer will secure the prisoner's presence, conditioned that the accused will appear upon a day named, before the municipal judge of the city, to await trial; and every such bond taken shall be filed as soon as practicable with the municipal court clerk by the officer approving and taking such bond; and the municipal judge, city clerk, municipal court clerk, mayor, chief of police and the desk sergeant or person in charge of police headquarters, and the county jailer shall each have the power to approve any bond taken under the provisions of this section, precedence being given to the ranking officer present at police headquarters when such bond is presented. No person shall be accepted as surety upon any penal bond unless he shall acknowledge the bond before some official duly authorized by law to administer an oath, and shall make oath that he is the owner in fee of real estate situate in the county and worth the amount of the bond over and above his debts and liabilities; but the officers named in this section are authorized and empowered to accept a deposit in cash of an amount which, in the judgment of the officer accepting the deposit, will be sufficient to cause the prisoner's appearance upon the day required of him before the municipal judge to await trial upon the charge against him. The amount of the deposit shall not be less than a sum sufficient in the judgment of the officer accepting the deposit to satisfy any reasonable fine and costs which may be imposed by the municipal judge. If any person so released upon bond or such deposit shall fail to appear before the municipal judge for trial at the appointed time, or, having appeared, shall leave the court without awaiting trial, his bond shall be forfeited to the city; and if a cash deposit has been made to secure his release, the sum so deposited shall be delivered to the municipal judge and promptly turned in by him to the city treasury to the credit of the general fund and accounted for by him in the same manner that fines collected by him are accounted for; and in the event of the forfeiture of a penal bond, the city solicitor shall forthwith take the steps necessary at law for the collection of the bond. 
(Code 1975, § 16-10) 
Sec. 38-41. - Requisites and disposition of cash deposit. 
    No cash bond shall be accepted by any officer authorized to accept such bonds unless the prisoner and the officer authorized to accept it are present at police headquarters or the booking desk. The money deposited as security for any person's appearance shall be deposited with the desk sergeant or jailer at the booking desk at police headquarters, to be safely kept by him until the next regular session of the municipal court, when it shall be turned over by the desk sergeant who received it to the municipal judge, and by the judge disposed of as required by the bond and this section and section 38-40. 
(Code 1975, § 16-11) 
Sec. 38-42. - Unlawful taking of cash deposit; approval of bond in felony cases. 
    If any officer shall accept or approve any cash bond at any place or in any other manner than is provided for and authorized in this article, such acceptance or approval shall constitute good cause for his suspension or removal or the reprimand or fining of such officer after a hearing on the charge by the city council. In case of the arrest of any person upon a charge of a felony, the bond for his release, if approved, shall only be approved by the municipal judge, or the judge of the intermediate court or circuit court of the county; and no other officer of the city shall be authorized to admit to bail any person charged with a felony. 
(Code 1975, § 16-12) 
State Law reference- Payment of fines by credit card, W. Va. Code § 8-10-2a. 
Sec. 38-43. - Who may not be bail sureties. 
    No practicing attorney, officer of the municipal court or member of the police force shall be accepted as surety on any bond provided for in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 16-13) 
Sec. 38-44. - Witness fees. 
    All witnesses (city officers and prosecutors excepted) duly summoned in any case before the municipal judge and attending at the trial shall be entitled to $0.50 for each day's attendance; but they shall not charge for attendance in more than one case on the same day, and every witness shall be deemed duly summoned who is sworn to testify in any case. 
(Code 1975, § 16-14) 
Sec. 38-45. - Separation of witnesses; exclusion of minors from courtroom. 
    The municipal judge is authorized to examine witnesses separate and apart from each other. He may also exclude all minors from the courtroom who may be present as mere spectators. 
(Code 1975, § 16-15) 
Sec. 38-46. - Procedure; new trials. 
    Trials may be conducted agreeably to law and established usage. New trials may be granted. 
(Code 1975, § 16-16) 
Sec. 38-47. - Acts punishable for contempt. 
    The municipal judge may punish for contempt a person guilty of any of the following acts: 
(1)  Contemptuous or insolent behavior towards the judge while engaged in the trial of a case or in any other judicial proceeding. 
(2)  Any breach of the peace, willful disturbance, or indecent conduct in the presence of the judge while so engaged, or so near as to obstruct or interrupt his proceedings. 
(3)  Violence or threats of violence to the judge or any officer, juror, witness or party going to, attending or returning from any judicial proceeding before the judge, in respect to anything done or to be done in the course of such proceeding. 
(4)  Misbehavior of any public officer in his official character in respect to any action or judicial proceeding had or pending before the judge, or any process, judgment, order or notice. 
(5)  Willful resistance, in the presence of the judge, by an officer, juror, witness, party or other person to any lawful process or order of such judge. 
(Code 1975, § 16-17) 
Sec. 38-48. - Prosecution for contempt. 
    An order to arrest may be issued by the municipal judge on which the person charged with the contempt may be taken and brought before him, or such person may be taken in custody by any officer or any person upon the oral order of the municipal judge and held to answer for the contempt. An opportunity must be given him to be heard in defense or explanation of his conduct, and the municipal judge may thereupon discharge him or adjudge him guilty of the contempt and punish him by fine or imprisonment or both. The fine shall not exceed $50.00 nor the imprisonment five days. The municipal judge shall not impose a fine for contempt unless the defendant is present in court, or shall have been served with a rule of the court to show cause, on some certain day, and shall have failed to appear and show cause. 
(Code 1975, § 16-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 50-5-11. 
Sec. 38-49. - Judgment and commitment for contempt. 
    The conviction for contempt, specifying the particular circumstances of the offense and judgment, must be entered by the municipal judge in his docket. A warrant of commitment for the term of imprisonment adjudged may be issued by the municipal judge commanding an officer to take the offender to the city or county jail, and the keeper to imprison him for the term stated. The judgment may include, in addition to fines, all costs in the case, including costs of arresting and keeping in prison the offender. 
(Code 1975, § 16-19) 
Sec. 38-50. - Intimidation of judicial officers, jurors and witnesses; obstructing administration of justice; penalty. 
    If any person by threats, force or otherwise intimidate or impede, or attempt to intimidate or impede the municipal judge, the municipal court clerk or deputy clerk, or any other officer of the municipal court or any juror or witness in the municipal court in the discharge of his duties as such, or by any means impede or obstruct or attempt to impede or obstruct the administration of justice in the municipal court, he shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-8. 
(Code 1975, § 16-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 61-5-27. 
Sec. 38-51. - False swearing and subornation of false swearing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly swear falsely under oath or affirmation lawfully administered in any trial or proceeding held in the municipal court or before the municipal judge, concerning any matter or thing, material or not material, or to procure another person to do so. 
(Code 1975, § 16-21) 
State Law reference- False swearing, W. Va. Code § 61-5-2. 
Sec. 38-52. - Imprisonment for fines and costs. 
    Subject to the provisions of division 3 of this article, when any fine is imposed for any violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city, the offender upon whom the fine has been imposed shall, in default of immediate payment of the fine and costs of prosecution, be committed to the city or county jail by the municipal judge until the fine and costs of prosecution shall be paid, or until otherwise discharged by due course of law, the term of imprisonment in such cases not to exceed 30 days. 
(Code 1975, § 16-22) 
Sec. 38-53. - Court costs. 
(a)  The city shall be entitled to and the municipal judge may at his discretion tax, in any case of conviction or confession, the regular costs of $1.00 plus the arrest fee for the police officers' pension and relief fund. 
(b)  In all cases of appeal from the judgment of the municipal court, the person seeking such appeal shall pay the municipal judge or municipal court clerk a fee of $1.00 for granting the appeal, including taking the bond or recognizance, making and certifying a transcript of the docket and transmitting it and the papers in the case to the clerk of the intermediate court. In all other cases not otherwise provided for, the fees shall be the same allowed justices for similar cases. All fees and costs shall accrue to the city. Neither the mayor, municipal judge, city clerk, municipal court clerk or any regular police officer shall be entitled to receive any fee for any services rendered in or about any trial or other proceeding touching a violation of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 16-23) 
Sec. 38-54. - Collection of fines and costs; remission; suspension of judgment. 
    The municipal judge shall be chargeable with all fines and costs imposed by him. Subject to the provisions of division 3 of this article, the municipal judge shall require the immediate payment of all fines and costs, and in default shall commit the defendant to jail for a term not to exceed 30 days, or until discharged by due process of law. He may collect fines and costs by execution to be directed to any police officer. The municipal judge shall have no power to remit any fine or costs imposed by him, except in cases of contempt. He may, for good cause, which shall be noted on his docket, suspend any judgment rendered by him. Where a party is imprisoned or otherwise held in custody under judgment of the municipal judge, it shall be upon a mittimus in due form. The municipal judge shall be credited with fines and costs in cases where judgment is suspended as provided in this division; in cases where the defendant is committed in default; in cases within the purview of division 3 of this article when the defendant is in default; and in cases where the execution is returned "no property found." 
(Code 1975, § 16-24) 
Secs. 38-55-38-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - JURIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Bill No. 7372, adopted Jan. 20, 2009, repealed §§ 38-81-38-103, and enacted §§ 38-81-38-90 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, §§ 16-36-58. 

Sec. 38-81. - Demand for jury trial. 
    Upon timely request by a defendant, the municipal court may hold a jury trial. A demand by the defendant for a jury trial must be made in writing not later than 20 days after the defendant's initial appearance before the municipal judge: Provided, that in the case of an indigent for whom counsel is to be appointed, the 20-day period shall not commence to run until counsel is appointed. Failure to demand within such time constitutes a waiver of the right to a trial by jury. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-82. - Persons eligible to jury service. 
    All persons who are at least 18 years of age and who are residents of the City of Charleston shall be liable to serve as jurors, except as provided in this division. Such jurors shall be of good character and free from felony crime convictions. 
    No juror shall be deemed incompetent because the city is a party to the matter to be tried and the juror is a resident of such city. 
    The municipal judge may, in his discretion, exempt or excuse any person from jury service when it appears that such service would be improper or work an undue hardship. A prospective juror 70 years of age or older is not disqualified from serving, but shall be excused from service by the court upon the juror's request. 
    Any prospective juror who has, within the preceding two years, been summoned to serve as a petit juror, grand juror, magistrate juror, or municipal juror, and has actually attended sessions of a circuit, magistrate or municipal court shall be disqualified to serve on a municipal jury. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-83. - Number of jurors. 
    The jury shall be comprised of 12 jurors. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-84. - Master jury list. 
    Jurors shall be selected from a list of registered city voters maintained by the city clerk. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-85. - Preparation of jury list for trial. 
    When a trial is scheduled in the municipal court, the court clerk shall no later than 15 days before the scheduled trial date: obtain a copy of the master jury list from the city clerk's office; randomly select the number of jurors required for municipal court from the panel or pool of jurors available for service; and contact or otherwise arrange for the jurors so selected to appear at the specified date, time and place of the municipal court trial. If, before the trial date, it becomes known that the jury panel will not be needed, the municipal clerk shall notify the scheduled jurors. (Rule 7.04 of the Trial Court Rules-Magistrate Court Juries) 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-86. - Penalty for failure of jurors to attend. 
    If any person duly summoned to attend as a juror shall neglect to attend, without any sufficient excuse, he shall pay a fine not exceeding $50.00, which shall be imposed by the municipal judge. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-87. - Discharge of jurors; excuse from attendance. 
    The court, when not incompatible with the proper dispatch of its business, shall have power to discharge persons summoned as jurors or dispense with their attendance on any day of its sitting. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-88. - When juror not entitled to compensation. 
    No juror who shall depart without leave of the municipal judge shall be entitled to receive any compensation for his services as a juror. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-89. - Payment of compensation. 
    Such jurors shall be paid at the rate of $20.00/day, inclusive of meal or travel cost within the city related to jury duty. Upon request and if available, jurors will be provided free parking in the Shanklin Parking Garage while serving as municipal jurors. It shall be the duty of the municipal court clerk, as soon as practicable after the adjournment of the court, or before the adjournment of the court at such time as the court may direct, to deliver to each juror a certified copy of any order making an allowance to him, payable out of the city treasury; and the treasurer shall, upon demand, pay to such juror the amount allowed to him. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 38-90. - Trial procedure. 
    Upon selection of a jury as set forth in Chapter 38 of the Code of the City of Charleston, the municipal court judge shall conduct a trial by jury consistent with the procedures set forth in the Rules of Criminal Procedure for West Virginia Magistrate Courts. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Secs. 38-91-38-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INSTALLMENT PAYMENT OF FINES AND COSTS 

Sec. 38-121. - Installment or other method of payment when defendant unable to pay forthwith. 
    Whenever a person is convicted in the municipal court of a violation of this Code or other ordinance or any rule, regulation, notice or order promulgated pursuant to authority, and such person is sentenced to pay a fine, and it shall appear to the court on its own motion or on motion of the defendant that such defendant is unable to pay such fine forthwith, the court may order the defendant to pay such fine and any costs which the defendant may be required to pay in installments or upon such other terms and conditions or within such period of time as may enable the defendant to pay such fine and costs. 
(Code 1975, § 16-25) 
Sec. 38-122. - Determination of ability to pay; questionnaire to be answered by defendant; assistance to defendant; penalty for false swearing. 
(a)  In determining whether a defendant is unable to pay a fine forthwith, the court may require such defendant to file a petition, under oath, with the court, upon a form provided by the court, setting forth the financial condition of the defendant. 
(b)  Such form shall be a questionnaire, and shall include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  The name and residence of the defendant; 
(2)  His occupation, if any; 
(3)  His family status and the number of persons dependent upon him; 
(4)  His monthly income; 
(5)  Whether or not his dependents are employed and, if so, their approximate monthly income; 
(6)  His banking accounts, if any; 
(7)  Real estate owned by the defendant, or any interest he may have in real estate; 
(8)  Income produced from such real estate; 
(9)  Any independent income accruing to the defendant; 
(10)  Tangible and intangible personal property owned by the defendant, or in which he may have an interest; and 
(11)  A statement listing the approximate indebtedness of the defendant to other persons. 
Such form shall also include a payment plan of the defendant if the court should exercise its discretion in permitting the payment of such fine and costs in installments or other conditions to be fixed by the court. At the end of such form there shall be printed in bold face type, in a distinctive color the following: 
    "THIS STATEMENT IS MADE UNDER OATH. ANY FALSE STATEMENT OF A MATERIAL FACT TO ANY QUESTION CONTAINED HEREIN SHALL CONSTITUTE FALSE SWEARING AND SHALL BE AN OFFENSE AGAINST THIS SECTION. THE MAXIMUM PENALTY IS $100.00 FINE OR 30 DAYS IN JAIL, OR BOTH." 
A copy of the petition shall be retained by the defendant. 
(c)  If the defendant is unable to read or write, the court or the clerk may assist the defendant in completing the petition and require him to affix his mark to the petition. The consequences of the making of a false statement shall be explained to such defendant. 
(d)  Any defendant who shall knowingly make a false statement of a material fact to any question contained in the questionnaire authorized by this section shall be guilty of false swearing under this section and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100.00 or 30 days' imprisonment, or both. 
(Code 1975, § 16-26) 
State Law reference- Authorized penalty for ordinance violations, W. Va. Code §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-5(57), 8-34-1. 
Sec. 38-123. - Payment of fine may be made condition of probation or suspension of sentence. 
    If a defendant is sentenced to pay a fine and payment of the fine or fine and costs is ordered to be made on an installment basis or on other conditions under the provisions of section 38-121; and if the defendant is also placed on probation or imposition of the execution of sentence is suspended, the court may make payment of the fine a condition of probation or suspension of sentence. 
(Code 1975, § 16-27) 
Sec. 38-124. - Court may require defendant to be on good behavior until fine and costs are paid. 
    If a defendant is permitted to pay a fine or fine and costs on an installment basis, or under such other conditions as the court shall fix under the provisions of section 38-121, the court may require as a condition that the defendant be of peace and good behavior until the fine and costs are paid. 
(Code 1975, § 16-28) 
Sec. 38-125. - Procedure upon default in payment under agreement; confinement in case of willful default. 
    When any person sentenced to pay a fine defaults in the payment of any such fine or of any installment of the fine, the court may issue a summons for such person to appear before the court for a hearing on the question of whether such person's failure to pay the fine or any installment was attributable to intentional refusal to comply with the prior order of the court or a lack of a good-faith effort to comply with the order. The court may, after hearing, order that the person in default be allowed additional time for payment, may reduce or remit the amount of the fine or the unpaid portion in whole or in part, or upon a finding that the default was intentional or due to the lack of a good-faith effort to comply with the prior order of the court, may order such person confined for such period up to 30 days as the court in its discretion shall determine. 
(Code 1975, § 16-29) 
Sec. 38-126. - Community service work may be substituted in lieu of incarceration or a fine in municipal court. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any provision of this Code to the contrary, the municipal judge may substitute in lieu of the imposition of a sentence of incarceration or imposition of a fine community service work for such incarceration or fine. Where community service work is ordered as a substitute for a sentence of incarceration, an eight-hour work day shall extinguish one day of any sentence of incarceration. Where community service work is ordered as a substitute for a fine, the prevailing federal minimum wage in effect at the time of sentencing shall be used to compute the hours of community service work necessary to extinguish the fine. In the discretion of the court, the sentence credits may run concurrently or consecutively. 
(b)  If approved by the court, any community service ordered pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be performed in the City of Charleston, and may be performed for the City of Charleston or for any other public entity or non-profit organization providing services that benefit the public and the City of Charleston. 
(c)  Persons sentenced under the provisions of this section remain under the jurisdiction of the municipal court. The court may withdraw the community service sentence at any time, with or without notice, and order a person previously sentenced to community service to serve the term of incarceration or to pay the fine available to the court upon the person's conviction: Provided, that any community service work performed before the community service sentence is withdrawn shall be credited against any term of incarceration or fine imposed. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009; Bill No. 7768, 11-20-2017) 
Sec. 38-127. - Home incarceration for municipal court offenders. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, when a person is convicted under a municipal ordinance for which a period of incarceration may be imposed, the municipal court may enter an order for home incarceration as an alternative sentence to incarceration in a county or regional jail; provided that home incarceration shall be available at the expense of the person convicted, and only if accepted by the Kanawha County Sheriff's Department Home Confinement Office. Any person accepted by the Kanawha County Sheriff's Department Home Confinement Office the home is required to enter into an agreement for payment of any related fees to the Kanawha County Sheriff's Department Home Confinement Office. 
(Bill No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Chapter 42 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY SERVICES DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency services, W. Va. Code § 15-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 42-31. - Organization created; composition; title. 
    There is created an emergency services organization for the city, which shall consist of a director, an emergency services council, and such other persons as are determined by the mayor or city council to be required. This organization may be referred to as the "Charleston-Kanawha Emergency Services Department." 
(Code 1975, § 7-1) 
State Law reference- Emergency services organization required, W. Va. Code § 15-5-8. 
Sec. 42-32. - Emergency services council. 
(a)  Created; composition; qualifications, appointment and term of members; filling vacancies. There is created a council to be known as the "Charleston-Kanawha Emergency Services Council, Charleston, West Virginia." The council shall consist of five members, all of whom shall be residents of the city, who shall be appointed by and serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. At no time shall more than three members of the council be members of the same political party. All members shall be appointed for terms of three years each and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified, but vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired terms. 
(b)  Compensation. Members of this council shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties as authorized by the mayor or city council. 
(c)  Advisory duties. The emergency services council shall advise the mayor and emergency services director on all matters pertaining to emergency service. 
(Code 1975, § 7-2) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-511 et seq. 
Sec. 42-33. - Functions of department. 
    The emergency services department shall perform emergency service functions within the territorial limits of the city and county and, in addition, shall conduct such functions outside such territorial limits as may be required pursuant to W. Va. Code ch. 15, art. 5 (W. Va. Code § 15-5-1 et seq.). The emergency services department shall ensure preparation in this city and county to deal with disaster resulting from enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action, and also from flood, fire, windstorm or other natural causes. In order that preparations in this city and county shall be adequate to deal with such disasters and generally to provide protection of the health, safety and public peace, and to preserve the lives and property of the people of the city and county, the emergency services department shall: 
(1)  Cooperate fully with the emergency services functions of the state and the county. 
(2)  Provide for the rendering of mutual aid to other cities and counties within the state and, if necessary and only with the specific approval of the mayor of Charleston and the governor, the neighboring counties and cities of another state. 
(3)  While cooperating with other agencies as provided in subsections (1) and (2) of this section, the emergency services department shall remain, insofar as practicable, a self-sustaining and independent unit. 
(Code 1975, § 7-3) 
Sec. 42-34. - Powers and duties of mayor. 
    The mayor shall have general direction and control of the emergency services department and shall be responsible for carrying out the provisions of this article and W. Va. Code ch. 15, art. 5 (W. Va. Code § 15-5-1 et seq.), insofar as it applies to the city. The mayor shall appoint such officials as are provided by this article. 
(Code 1975, § 7-4) 
Sec. 42-35. - Appointment, term and compensation of director. 
    The mayor is authorized and directed to appoint an emergency services director for the city. The emergency services director shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor and be paid such compensation as is determined by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 7-5) 
Sec. 42-36. - Director's powers and duties. 
(a)  Department head. The emergency services director, subject to the direction and control of the mayor, shall be the executive head of the emergency services department and shall, subject to such control, have the direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of the city organization for emergency services. The director shall coordinate the activities of all organizations for emergency services within the city and shall cooperate with the emergency services agencies and organizations in the county and the state. 
(b)  Coordination; other duties. The director shall coordinate all the activities of agencies, public or private, in all matters and actions during an emergency. In performing the duties under this article and to effect its policy and purpose, the director is further authorized, directed and empowered to: 
(1)  Prepare a comprehensive plan and program for the emergency services of the city, such plan or program to be coordinated with the emergency services plans of the state and county, and of other cities and counties in the state. 
(2)  In accordance with such plan and program for the emergency services of the city, procure supplies and equipment, institute training programs and public information programs and take all other preparatory steps, including the partial or full mobilization of all city emergency services organizations in advance of actual disaster in order to ensure the furnishing of adequately trained and equipped forces of emergency service personnel in time of need. 
(3)  Make such studies and surveys of the resources and facilities in the city as may be necessary to ascertain the capabilities of the city for emergency services and to plan their most efficient emergency use. 
(4)  On behalf of the city, enter into mutual aid arrangements with the county emergency services and, with the approval of the county, with other counties and cities in the state and, with the approval of the mayor and of the governor, with other emergency services organizations in other states, for reciprocal emergency services, aid and assistance in case of disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. 
(5)  Delegate any administrative authority invested in the director under this article and to provide for the subdelegation of any such authority. 
(6)  Fully cooperate with the state and county emergency services and with officials and agencies of other cities and counties within the state in matters pertaining to the emergency services of the city, county or state, including the direction and/or control of: 
a.  Blackouts and practice blackouts, air raid drills, mobilization of emergency services forces, and tests and exercises. 
b.  Warnings and signals for drills or attacks and the connected mechanical devices to be used. 
c.  The effective screening or extinguishing of all lights and lighting devices and appliances. 
d.  Shutting off water mains, gas mains or electric power connections of any or all other utility services when necessary and authorized by law. 
e.  The conduct of civilians and the movement and/or cessation of movement of pedestrians and vehicular traffic during, prior to and subsequent to drills or attacks or during any time of emergency as duly declared by the mayor. 
f.  All public meetings or gatherings. 
g.  The evacuation and reception of civilian population. 
h.  All rescue operations. 
(7)  Prepare and amend, not less than annually and with the approval of city council, a plan of emergency operations consistent with the requirements of the federal, state or city governments, to be designated "City of Charleston Emergency Operations Plan." 
(Code 1975, § 7-6) 
Sec. 42-37. - Appropriations and authority to accept services, gifts, grants and loans. 
(a)  Whenever the federal, state or county government, or any agency or officer, shall offer to the city services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift, grant or loan for any of the purposes of this article, the emergency services director of the city, acting with the consent of the mayor, may accept such offer subject to the rules and regulations, if any, of the agency making the offer. 
(b)  Whenever any person shall offer to the city any services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift, grant or loan, the emergency services director, acting with the consent of the mayor, may accept such offer subject to the terms of the offer. 
(Code 1975, § 7-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, W. Va. Code § 15-5-13. 
Sec. 42-38. - Utilization of existing services and facilities; volunteer assistance. 
(a)  In carrying out the provisions of this article, the director is directed and authorized to utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments of the city to the maximum extent practicable; and the department heads and all personnel of the various departments are directed to cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the director upon request. 
(b)  Whenever volunteer assistance is needed in any emergency, the call shall be made by the emergency services department; and all volunteers will report where directed to an emergency services representative to be registered and assigned. No unregistered volunteers will be used by any department of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 7-8) 
Sec. 42-39. - Political activity prohibited.
