Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; courts, ch. 38; emergency services, ch. 46. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Police departments generally, W. Va. Code § 8-14-1; police department authorized, W. Va. Code § 8-14-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-31. - Chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall be the commanding officer of the police department and shall be responsible for the administration, training, discipline and morale of the members of the department and for their effective deployment and utilization to preserve and maintain law and order in the city, and beyond the city limits in those areas which are within the police jurisdiction of the city as provided in section 85 of the city's Charter and as further provided in W. Va. Code §§ 8-12-5(32), (33), (43) and 8-12-19 and to enforce all applicable provisions of state law, this Code and other ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 22-1) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-131 et seq. 
Sec. 66-32. - Chain of command; obedience to orders. 
    The chain of command within the police department shall flow through the chief of police to the other officers and police officers downward in order of rank and seniority within rank; and subordinates shall have the powers and perform the duties of their immediate superiors when such superiors are absent or disabled. Each member of the police department shall obey all lawful orders of his superiors in the chain of command, and any disobedience to or failure to comply with any such order shall subject the member to such disciplinary action or penalty that may be set forth in the police manual. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2) 
Sec. 66-33. - Police manual adopted; where filed and available for inspection; violations; short title. 
    For the purpose of providing for the organization, government, policies, rules, procedures and discipline of the city police department, and for other related purposes, there is adopted the operations manual for the city police department's policies, rules and procedures, a copy of which is and shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk, and another copy which is and shall remain on file at police headquarters for inspection and use by all members of the city police department. Such manual is hereby incorporated in and made a part of this section as fully as though it were set out in length, and any member of the police department who violates or fails to comply with any provisions of the manual adopted by this section shall be subject to such disciplinary action or penalty as may be provided in such manual. The manual adopted by this section may be known and be simply cited as "The Police Manual of the Charleston Police Department." 
(Code 1975, § 22-3) 
Sec. 66-34. - Updating manual provisions. 
    The chief of police, may from time to time prepare amendments and additions to and deletions from the police manual; and each such amendment, addition or deletion, or any combination, when approved by the mayor and when filed in the office of the city clerk for public inspection and use, with a copy being on file in the headquarters of the police department for inspection and use by all members of the department, shall be binding on all members of the department; and it shall be grounds for disciplinary action or penalty for any member of the police department to violate or fail to comply with any such amendment or addition which has been so promulgated, approved and filed. 
(Code 1975, § 22-4) 
Sec. 66-35. - Policemen's civil service commission. 
    Pursuant to the requirements of W. Va. Code § 8-14-7, there is created the "Policemen's Civil Service Commission of the City of Charleston, West Virginia." Such commission shall be constituted and its members shall possess the qualifications and be chosen in the manner and hold office for the term and period of time as provided by W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 14, pt. V (W. Va. Code § 8-14-6 et seq.). 
(Code 1975, § 22-5) 
State Law reference- Civil service for police departments in class I cities, W. Va. Code § 8-14-6 et seq. 
Sec. 66-36. - Policemen's pension and relief fund; trustees. 
(a)  Pursuant to the requirements of W. Va. Code § 8-22-16 there is established a policemen's pension and relief fund. 
(b)  There is created a board of trustees to be known as "The Board of Trustees of the Policemen's Pension and Relief Fund of the City of Charleston, West Virginia." Such board shall be constituted and its members shall possess the qualifications and be chosen in the manner and hold office for the term and period of time, all according to and as provided by W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 22, pt. III (W. Va. Code § 8-22-16 et seq.). 
(c)  The policemen's pension and relief fund established by this section shall be maintained and administered by the board of trustees in conformity with the provisions of W. Va. Code ch. 8, art. 22, pt. III (W. Va. Code § 8-22-16 et seq.). 
(Code 1975, § 22-6) 
State Law reference- Police officers' pension and relief fund, W. Va. Code § 8-22-16 et seq. 
Sec. 66-37. - Workers' compensation; pay of police officers injured in performance of duty. 
(a)  The city shall subscribe to the workers' compensation fund of the compensation commission of the state for the protection of members of the city police department, and any member of the police department injured while acting in the performance of his official duty as a member of the police department shall be entitled to receive temporary compensation from the state compensation fund as a result of such injury. 
(b)  In addition to the workers' compensation benefits, such member is receiving, such member shall receive such supplemental pay from the city, for a period not to exceed one year, that will bring the amount paid to such member by the workers' compensation fund and/or any pension fund benefits such member is receiving to an amount equaling 100 percent of the net compensation which is paid to such member while working in his position with the city. Benefits paid under this section, including supplemental pay, shall not be received under this section if such member is receiving benefits under the sick leave provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 22-7) 
State Law reference- Mandatory participation in workers' compensation, W. Va. Code § 23-2-1. 
Sec. 66-38. - Contribution toward police officers' uniforms. 
    In addition to such compensation as may otherwise be allowed and paid to members of the police department, the city shall reimburse each member of the police department for the cost to him of items of clothing which comprise a part of the official uniform and on-duty clothing purchased, used and worn by him, to an aggregate maximum amount to be determined from time to time by the city council; provided, that no portion of such allowance to any member remaining unexpended at the end of any fiscal year shall be carried over into the next or any succeeding fiscal year. Such reimbursement may be made by payment directly to each such police officers or by payment directly to the vendor or furnisher of each such item of clothing, upon and after conformity and compliance with such rules, regulations, proceedings, forms and proofs as may be prescribed and promulgated from time to time by the chief of police upon the advice and with the approval of the city auditor. 
(Code 1975, § 22-8) 
Sec. 66-39. - Sale of abandoned property recovered by police. 
(a)  The city manager shall, every six months, sell at public auction at the front door of city hall or some other place designated by him all property of every kind and character abandoned and recovered by the police department and to which no claim has been made by anyone entitled to possession of such property. None of the property described in this section shall be sold within 30 days after it shall have been recovered. No separate item of property having a value of more than $20.00, which value shall be determined by the city manager, shall be sold until the sale shall have been advertised as a class 1 legal advisement, the advisement to contain a description of the property to be sold. The city manager shall make a full and complete report of all such sales and pay the proceeds to the finance director and take from him a receipt, and the proceeds are appropriated to the general fund. The auction provisions shall not apply to United States or foreign currency or coins. 
(b)  Any property not sold as prescribed in subsection (a) of this section shall be destroyed by an officer of the police department, who shall be designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1975, § 22-9) 
Secs. 66-40-66-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DUTY HOURS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER LEAVE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Hours of duty for policemen in paid police department under civil service, etc., W. Va. Code § 8-14-2. 

Sec. 66-61. - Daily and weekly duty hours; eight-hour shift; overtime pay. 
    All sworn members of the police department shall be subject to duty 24 hours a day, if necessary, at the discretion of the chief of police. However, the normal work week for all department members assigned to eight-hour shifts will be 40 hours. The work week will begin at 12:01 a.m., Sunday and end at 12:00 midnight the following Saturday night, consisting of seven consecutive, 24-hour periods. Overtime pay shall be governed by the maximum hours prescribed under the applicable state or federal law. 
(Code 1975, § 22-10; Bill No. 7640, 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-62. - Daily and weekly duty hours; twelve-hour shift; overtime pay. 
    All sworn members of the police department shall be subject to duty 24 hours a day, if necessary, at the discretion of the chief of police. However, the normal work week for all department members assigned to a 12-hour shift will be a biweekly schedule as assigned by the chief or his designee. The work week will begin at 12:01 a.m., Sunday and end at 12:00 midnight the following Saturday night, consisting of seven consecutive 24-hour periods. Overtime pay shall be governed by the maximum hours prescribed under the applicable state or federal law. 
(Code 1975, § 22-10.5; Bill No. 7640, 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-63. - Vacation leave. 
    Each sworn member of the police department shall be given a monthly vacation leave credit of ten hours during the first 15 years of service; thereafter, he shall be credited on the basis of 13 hours and 20 minutes a month. Vacations shall be taken as such time as permitted by the chief of police. No more than 240 hours of vacation leave can be accumulated at any one time. 
(Code 1975, § 22-11) 
Sec. 66-64. - Legal holidays. 
(a)  The following days shall be regarded, treated and observed as legal holidays: 
(1)  January 1, New Year's Day; 
(2)  The third Monday of January, Martin Luther King's Birthday; 
(3)  The third Monday of February, Presidents' Day; 
(4)  The last Monday in May, Memorial Day; 
(5)  June 20, West Virginia Day; 
(6)  July 4, Independence Day; 
(7)  The first Monday of September, Labor Day; 
(8)  The second Monday of October, Columbus Day; 
(9)  November 11, Veterans Day; 
(10)  The fourth Thursday and Friday of November, Thanksgiving Day Holidays; 
(11)  December 25, Christmas Day; 
(12)  Any national, state or other election day throughout the district or municipality wherein the election is held, provided, that if a special or other election of a political subdivision other than the City of Charleston falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the City of Charleston may choose not to recognize the day of the election as a holiday if a majority of the City of Charleston City Council votes not to recognize the day of the election as a holiday; and 
(13)  All days which may be appointed or recommended by the mayor, the governor or the President of the United States as days of thanksgiving or for the general cessation of business. 
    When any of such days or dates falls on Saturday or Sunday, either the preceding Friday of the succeeding Monday shall be regarded, treated and observed as such legal holiday. 
(b)  A sworn member of the police department who is assigned to an eight-hour shift schedule and is required to work on a legal holiday, as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, shall either be paid for those hours worked during the holiday period, not to exceed eight hours, at his regular hourly rate of pay or be allowed to add up to eight hours of equal time off, which may be taken at such time as approved by the chief of police. If the legal holiday falls on his regularly scheduled day off, he shall be allowed eight hours of equal time off, which may be taken at such time as approved by the chief of police. 
(c)  A sworn member of the police department who is assigned to a 12-hour shift schedule and is required to work his entire 12 hours on a legal holiday, as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, shall either be paid for an extra 12 hours at his regular hourly rate or be allowed to add 12 hours of equal time off, which may be taken at such time as approved by the chief of police. If the legal holiday falls on his regularly scheduled day off, he shall be allowed 12 hours of equal time off, which may be taken at such time as approved by the chief of police. 
(d)  A sworn member of the police department who is assigned to a 12-hour shift schedule and is required to work a portion of his 12-hour shift on a legal holiday, as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, shall, for those hours actually worked during the holiday period, either be paid an amount equal to his regular hourly rate times the period of time worked on the holiday or be allowed to add an equal amount of time off, which may be taken at such time as approved by the chief of police. For that portion of his 12-hour shift that does not fall within the holiday period, the member shall be allowed an equal amount of time off, which may be taken at such time as approved by the chief of police. 
(Code 1975, § 22-12; Bill No. 7144, 5-16-2005; Bill No. 7175, 11-21-2005; Bill No. 7640, 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-65. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Beginning January 1, 2015, each uniformed member shall be entitled to and granted sick leave with full pay. Such leave shall accrue at the rate of eight hours credited on the last day of each month during which the member has worked or has had leave credited for one or more tours of duty. 
(b)  When a member retires, the member will have the privilege of converting up to 96 hours of sick leave accrued under subsection 66-65(a) on or after January 1, 2015, or any remaining unused sick leave accrued prior to January 1, 2015, whichever is greater, to insurance benefits based on the formula of 16 hours for one month single coverage insurance premium or 24 hours for one month family coverage insurance premium. Any sick leave accrued by a member under subsection 66-65(a) on or after January 1, 2015, that is not converted to insurance benefits to the extent permitted by this section shall be forfeited effective as of the date of the member's retirement or separation from employment. 
(c)  Sick leave shall only be granted for the following reasons: 
(1)  Illness on the part of or injury to the member, incapacitating him for duty. 
(2)  Illness in the immediate family, i.e. husband, wife, child, father, mother, sister, brother, father-in-law and mother-in-law, of such a critical nature as to require the presence of the member. This provision shall not be construed as to cover absences for the purposes of nursing or caring for immediate family members not declared by the attending physician to be critically ill. 
(3)  Exposure to a contagious disease and subsequent determination by competent medical authority that the member's presence on duty might jeopardize the health of others. 
(d)  A member shall be required to furnish to the chief of police a certificate from the attending physician for all consecutive days of sick leave granted beyond three working days. 
(e)  After the equivalent of half of annual sick leave has been used in single-day events, a member shall furnish documentation from a physician or other medical provider establishing reason for relief from duty for use of additional sick leave for single-day events. 
(f)  In cases of emergency, the chief of police may, at his discretion, grant advance sick leave up to 240 hours beyond that accumulated provided that all regularly earned sick and vacation leave has been used. 
(g)  The chief of police shall otherwise have the right to investigate or cause to be investigated the alleged illness of any member and, for good cause shown, to not only deny sick leave but also to take proper disciplinary action against any feigner or abuser. 
(h)  In the event of any emergency, as declared by the mayor, an attending physician's excuse may be required for any days missed; and, further, during such emergency, the mayor may suspend, in whole or in part, any sick leave as permitted by subsection (c) of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 22-13; Ord. No. 4939, 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 4960, § 22-13, 6-7-1993; Bill No. 7640, 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-66. - Funeral leave with pay. 
    In the case of the death of the husband, wife, child, mother, father, brother, sister, mother-in-law or father-in-law, or in the case of death of any other relative residing in the immediate household, the member shall be allowed two days funeral leave with regular pay without deduction from his accumulated vacation or sick leave. In the case of death of a sister-in-law, brother-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law, grandparent, grandchild, aunt, uncle, nephew, niece or first cousin of the member or spouse, the member shall be allowed one day funeral leave with regular pay without deduction from his accumulated vacation or sick leave. In addition, the employee may be allowed by the police chief to use two days of his accumulated sick leave in the case of death of any of these persons. 
(Code 1975, § 22-13.1) 
Sec. 66-67. - Immunizations. 
    As a condition of employment, all police officers are to be immunized by hepatitis B vaccine. 
(Ord. No. 4810, 3-22-1993) 
Secs. 66-68-66-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SCHOOL CROSSING GUARDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-131 et seq. 
State Law reference- Special school zone police officers, W. Va. Code § 8-14-5. 

Sec. 66-91. - Authorized to be appointed by mayor, for assignment by chief of police. 
    The mayor is authorized to appoint qualified persons as civilian school crossing guards in such numbers as he may deem necessary to serve at his will and pleasure, such guards to be assigned to such school crossings within the city as the chief of police shall determine. 
(Code 1975, § 22-14) 
Sec. 66-92. - Rules and regulations; compensation and hours of duty. 
    The chief of police shall promulgate rules relating to the qualifications and duties of civilian school crossing guards, who shall be paid at such rate as may be authorized by the city council, for services not to exceed three hours per day for 180 days each year when public, private or parochial schools are in session. 
(Code 1975, § 22-15) 
Sec. 66-93. - Powers and duties; violations; training. 
    Civilian school crossing guards shall direct and guide schoolchildren at school crossings in the area to which they may be assigned from time to time on days when public, private or parochial schools are in session; and they shall assist the city police in the direction of traffic upon such other occasions as the chief of police shall direct. No civilian school crossing guard shall have the power of arrest, but it shall be the duty of such guard to report immediately any violations of the law to the police department and to sign a complaint for and prosecute such violations in the municipal court of the city. Failure of any civilian school crossing guard to perform such duty shall be a violation of this section. Training and supervision of such civilian school crossing guards shall be under the direction of the chief of police. 
(Code 1975, § 22-16) 
Sec. 66-94. - Uniforms and equipment. 
    Civilian school crossing guards shall wear such badges, dress and insignia as the chief of police shall direct and shall be equipped in the manner which he deems necessary for the proper discharge of their duties, all such badges, dress, insignia and equipment to be furnished by and at the expense of the city. It shall be unlawful for any civilian school crossing guard to exercise authority as such guard or to wear the uniform or insignia or to display the badge in an attempt to exercise authority except during the performance of duties assigned by the chief of police. 
(Code 1975, § 22-17) 
Secs. 66-95-66-110. - Reserved.

Sec. 66-111. - Created. 
    There is created the Citizens Commission of the Charleston Mounted Police Patrol. 
(Ord. No. 5051, § 2-182, 11-15-1993) 
Sec. 66-112. - Membership. 
    The commission created in this division shall consist of 50 appointed members, who shall be appointed by the mayor and serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. Two councilmembers shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5051, § 2-183, 11-15-1993) 
Sec. 66-113. - General purpose. 
    The general purpose of the commission created in this division shall be to promote and assist in the operation of the mounted police patrol, including but not limited to raising funds for the construction, operation and maintenance of facilities for housing horses, and for the expenses of transportation in connection with such activities, and any and all other expenses incident to the operation of the mounted police patrol. 
(Ord. No. 5051, § 2-184, 11-15-1993) 
Sec. 66-114. - Declaration of council. 
    The council declares the citizens commission to be an agent or board of the city within the meaning of section 1-10 and other applicable ordinances and resolutions, for the purpose of providing the citizens commission the protection of the insurance policies required under that section, and any immunity provided by that section for liability arising from or growing out of or in any way connected with acts or omissions of the citizens commission in the performance of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 5051, § 2-185, 11-15-1993) 
Secs. 66-115-66-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY JAIL 

Sec. 66-151. - Penalties. 
    Whoever shall violate any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-8. 
(Code 1975, § 16-35) 
Sec. 66-152. - Payment of fine; discharge of prisoners. 
    Any city prisoner may at any time pay the municipal judge the amount stated in the mittimus or balance due after deducting such credits as he may be entitled to; and upon such payment, or upon any prisoner working out his fine and costs or the term of imprisonment imposed by the municipal court judge, or if he should be otherwise legally entitled to his discharge, the officer having custody of the prisoner shall give the prisoner a printed or written discharge and set him at liberty. A duplicate of such discharge shall be filed with the municipal judge. The municipal judge is empowered to release any city prisoner for good cause shown, and to fix the terms upon which the prisoner may be released. In any event, a written order shall be filed with the municipal court clerk and the prisoner's custodian showing the reason for release and the terms, if any, upon which it was made. 
(Code 1975, § 16-30) 
Sec. 66-153. - Escape of prisoners generally. 
    Any person confined in any place of imprisonment maintained by the city, or who is confined in the county jail as a city prisoner, who escapes by force, violence or by any subterfuge, device or deception, or any person while so confined who is released to the custody of any city employee for the purpose of supervision by the city employee of the prisoner's work and labor who escapes shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1975, § 16-31) 
State Law reference- Escapes, W. Va. Code § 61-5-8 et seq. 
Sec. 66-154. - City officers and employees not to permit escapes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any city officer or employee voluntarily to suffer a prisoner, lawfully in his custody or lawfully confined within a place which is in his custody, to escape; and each city officer and employee having custody of a city prisoner shall use all the necessary means to prevent escape of the prisoner. 
(Code 1975, § 16-32) 
State Law reference- Permitting escape of prisoner or refusing to take custody of prisoner, W. Va. Code § 61-5-9. 
Sec. 66-155. - Giving prohibited articles to prisoners. 
    No person shall deliver or give to any city prisoner lawfully confined in any jail or other place of imprisonment any intoxicating drink or other article of any kind without the permission of the municipal judge or the health commissioner. 
(Code 1975, § 16-34) 
Chapter 70 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 50; health and sanitation, ch. 58; planning, ch. 90; solid waste, ch. 98; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 102; subdivision regulations, ch. 106; utilities, ch. 118; zoning, app. B; MH mobile home district, app. B, § 17-1 et seq. 
State Law reference- The West Virginia Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act, W. Va. Code § 21-9-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAILERS AND TRAILER CAMPS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 70-31-70-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AUTO TRAILER CAMPS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 70-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Auto trailer means any building or structure used for living or sleeping purposes and equipped with wheels or other means to facilitate movement from place to place, and automobiles, when used for living or sleeping purposes. 
    Auto trailer camp means any lot or parcel of land used or intended to be used for the accommodation of two or more auto trailers. 
    Camp sewer means a sewer constructed in any auto trailer camp for the service of auto trailers and connected to the city sewer, or in case there is no city sewer in any street on which such auto trailer camp abuts, to a septic tank as required by section 118-74. 
    Trailer unit means a plot of land in an auto trailer camp used or intended to be used for the accommodation of not more than one auto trailer and not more than one automobile which is not an auto trailer. 
(Code 1975, § 30-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-52. - Violations and penalties. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this division shall upon conviction be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8; and each day during any portion of which a violation of this division is committed, continued or permitted shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed a public nuisance, and may be summarily abated as such by the officers of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 30-22) 
Sec. 70-53. - Person in charge of auto trailer camp; camp office and register. 
(a)  The owner or operator of every auto trailer camp, before allowing any auto trailers in the camp, shall file with the chief of police and health commissioner the name of the person who will be in continuous responsible charge of the camp, and who is authorized to act for him. Any change in such person in charge shall be immediately reported to these officers. 
(b)  In every auto trailer camp there shall be an office building in which shall be located the office of the person in charge of the camp. The camp register shall at all times be kept in the office. 
(Code 1975, § 30-10) 
Sec. 70-54. - Duties of owners and persons in charge of auto trailer camps. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, operator or person in charge of any auto trailer camp to: 
(1)  Keep at all times a register of all persons staying in his camp, which register shall at all times be open to the officers of the city and which register shall record the names and home addresses of all persons staying in the auto trailer camp, the date of their arrival, date of their departure, the number of and state in which the driver's license of such person was issued, the license number of all auto trailers and automobiles in the camp, the name of the state or country in which they are registered, the trailer unit on which each is located and the place at which the last overnight stop was made; 
(2)  Maintain the camp in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all times; 
(3)  Allow no more than one auto trailer and one automobile on any one trailer unit at any one time; 
(4)  Require that all such auto trailers and automobiles are located on their respective trailer units as required by the terms of this division; 
(5)  Require all toilets in every auto trailer in the camp to be connected to the camp sewer or in case any toilet is so constructed that it cannot be so connected, to require it to be sealed so that it cannot be used during the total time it shall remain in the camp; 
(6)  Require every sink and every lavatory in any auto trailer in the camp to be connected to the camp sewer during its entire stay in the camp; 
(7)  See that all required lights are kept lighted as provided in this division; 
(8)  See that all garbage is drained and wrapped as required by ordinance and deposited in the garbage cans required by section 70-56 and see that all such garbage cans are collected, cleaned and redistributed as required by that subsection; 
(9)  Permit no domestic animal in the camp unless such animal is kept on a leash or is confined in an adequate enclosure; 
(10)  Report promptly to the proper authorities any violations of law which may come to his attention; 
(11)  See that no person overstays his legal limit of residence in the camp; and 
(12)  Post in a waterproof holder in a conspicuous place in each trailer unit a copy of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 30-11) 
Sec. 70-55. - Auto trailer camp layout. 
(a)  Every auto trailer camp shall have access to a public street either by abutting directly on such street or by means of a private road not less than ten feet wide. Along one side of such private road for its full length shall be a walkway not less than three feet wide and raised six inches above the roadway. Such roadway from the street line in and every road required by the terms of this division within any auto trailer camp shall be paved or constructed in a manner suitable to the city engineer. 
(b)  Roadways not less than ten feet wide shall be provided in every auto trailer camp so located that each and every trailer unit shall have direct access thereto. 
(c)  The entire area of every auto trailer camp, exclusive of roadways, well-maintained lawns and planted areas, shall be thoroughly graveled or paved. 
(d)  Every auto trailer camp shall be surrounded on all sides, except those sides directly abutting on a public street, with a fence not less than six feet high constructed and maintained so as effectively to prevent the passage of persons. There shall be no opening or gate in such fence except with the written approval of the owner of the immediately adjoining land, which approval shall be filed with the health commissioner. 
(e)  Each trailer unit in every auto trailer camp shall contain not less than 600 square feet of ground and shall not be less than 25 feet in minimum width measured at right angles to the side lines. The boundary lines of every trailer unit shall be plainly and permanently marked or otherwise indicated. 
(f)  The setbacks established by the zoning ordinance shall apply equally to trailer units and to buildings of the same outside dimensions. 
(g)  There shall be not less than five feet between any part of any auto trailer and any boundary line of the trailer unit on which it is located. 
(h)  No automobiles or tow cars parked on any trailer unit shall extend beyond the boundaries of the unit. 
(Code 1975, § 30-12) 
Sec. 70-56. - Sanitation. 
(a)  On each trailer unit, there shall be a connection to a camp sewer arranged so that the sanitary fixtures in any auto trailer may be readily connected to the sewer. Immediately after being placed on a trailer unit, every auto trailer shall have all its sanitary fixtures connected to the sewer or sealed so that they cannot be used. Every such connection shall be by means of rigid pipe. Hose connections are not permissible. 
(b)  On each trailer unit, there shall be an ample supply of water for the use of the occupants of the unit. There shall be two outlets on such service, both of which shall be adapted for hose connection. 
(c)  In every auto trailer camp, there shall be provided not less than one public toilet for each sex for every ten trailer units or fraction thereof. In addition, there shall be one urinal for every ten trailer units. All toilet and urinal rooms shall have hard, smooth finished, cement floors and shall have walls plastered with Portland cement plaster with a polished steel trowel finish. All corners shall be rounded with a fillet of not less than one-half-inch radius. Walls and floors may be finished in nonabsorbent tile in lieu of the cement finish. 
(d)  In every auto trailer camp, there shall be provided one bathtub or stall shower for each sex for every ten trailer units or fraction. All such baths shall be provided at all times with an ample supply of hot and cold water. Bathrooms shall be constructed as specified for toilet rooms in subsection (c) of this section. 
(e)  In every auto trailer camp, there shall be provided not less than one double-compartment laundry tray and one lavatory for every ten trailer units; and all such fixtures shall be at all times provided with an ample supply of hot and cold water. All such fixtures shall be installed in rooms constructed as specified for toilet rooms in subsection (c) of this section. All bathrooms shall be supplied with adequate heating equipment maintained in proper operating condition. 
(f)  In every auto trailer camp, there shall be provided not less than one sink and one slop sink for every ten trailer units; and such fixtures shall be supplied with an adequate supply of hot and cold water. 
(g)  No trailer unit shall be more than 200 feet from any of the sanitary fixtures required by this section to serve the trailer unit. 
(h)  Under and around every laundry tray, sink, lavatory and slop sink, there shall be a concrete or tile floor; and such floor shall extend three feet in all directions beyond such fixture. 
(i)  Every trailer unit shall be provided with a substantial covered garbage can as required by ordinance for residences in the city. Such garbage can shall be kept on a concrete pavement not less than three feet square and four inches thick, with a smooth troweled top. In every auto trailer camp, all such garbage cans shall be collected at one convenient place prior to garbage collection time on each day on which garbage is collected in that district. Immediately after the garbage has been collected, all such cans shall be carefully cleaned and returned to their respective trailer units. 
(j)  Every auto trailer camp shall be provided with a masonry incinerator, of a size suitable to handle the combustible wastes of the camp, and located as directed by the fire chief. 
(k)  In every auto trailer camp where automobiles or trailers are washed or are to be washed, there shall be installed a wash rack; and no such washing shall be done except on such wash rack. All such wash racks shall be paved with a continuous concrete floor slab not less than 15 feet by 25 feet by four inches thick, and all parts shall slope toward a drain so connected as to dispose of all wastewater without nuisance or creation of an unsanitary condition. 
(Code 1975, § 30-13) 
Sec. 70-57. - Lights in public rooms. 
    Every public toilet and every public urinal room shall be lighted from one-half hour after sunset of each day until one-half hour before sunrise of the succeeding day. Such lighting shall be provided in an amount not less than one-half watt per square foot of floor area in any such room. Every public bath, laundry tray, sink and slop sink shall be supplied with lights which may be turned on by the person using such room. 
(Code 1975, § 30-14) 
Sec. 70-58. - Electrical connections. 
(a)  Every trailer unit shall be furnished with an electric service outlet which shall be equipped with an externally operated switch, a fuse of not less than 30 amperes' capacity, and a heavy-duty outlet receptacle. 
(b)  All electrical work in every auto trailer camp shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the electrical code of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 30-15) 
Sec. 70-59. - Compliance with plumbing code. 
    In every auto trailer camp all plumbing work shall comply with the requirements of the plumbing code of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 30-16) 
Sec. 70-60. - Compliance with building codes. 
    In every auto trailer camp, all buildings and structures other than auto trailers shall comply with the city building code and the BOCA Basic Building Code. 
(Code 1975, § 30-17) 
Sec. 70-61. - Effect of zoning ordinance. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit the erection and maintenance in any auto trailer camp of any building or structure which is permissible under the terms of the zoning ordinance for the zone in which the auto trailer camp is located. 
(Code 1975, § 30-18) 
Sec. 70-62. - Fire protection. 
(a)  Every auto trailer camp shall be provided with one or more standpipes not less than 11/2 inches in diameter, and such standpipes shall be provided with 11/2-inch fire hose of such lengths that every part of such auto trailer camp may be reached with the hose, and each such hose shall be equipped with a standard nozzle. All such hose shall be kept on a reel or rack, protected from the weather, and shall be used for no purpose other than fire protection. 
(b)  Every auto trailer camp shall be provided with not less than two acid and soda, 21/2-gallon fire extinguishers located as directed by the fire chief. 
(Code 1975, § 30-19) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 54. 
Sec. 70-63. - Parking on street. 
    No auto trailer or other trailer as defined in section 114-1 shall be permitted to park on any street in the city overnight. 
(Code 1975, § 30-20) 
Cross reference- Traffic ordinance, ch. 114. 
Sec. 70-64. - Storage of trailer on owner's premises. 
    Nothing in this division shall be deemed to prohibit the storage of any auto trailer on the home premises of its owner for any length of time when not used for living or sleeping purposes. 
(Code 1975, § 30-21) 
Secs. 70-65-70-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permit 

Sec. 70-101. - Limitations on maintaining auto trailers on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, keep or maintain any auto trailer on any land within the city without the express permission of the owner of such land; and no person shall allow, suffer or permit any auto trailer to be placed, kept or maintained on any land owned or controlled by him except in an auto trailer camp for which a permit has been issued by the health commissioner; provided, that the occupant of any single-family dwelling may allow not more than one auto trailer of a nonpaying guest to be placed, kept or maintained on the property for a period not exceeding three months in any period of 12 months by procuring a permit as provided in section 70-103 and otherwise complying with the related provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 30-2) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit location of occupied house trailers or mobile homes in residential areas, W. Va. Code § 8-12-5(30). 
Sec. 70-102. - Auto trailer camp permits. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of this division, auto trailer camps may be established and maintained in this city. 
(b)  Permits issued for auto trailer camps by the health commissioner shall expire one year from the date of issue unless renewed as provided. If the auto trailer camp is to be maintained for a period longer than one year, a renewal of the permit shall be obtained from the health commissioner. Such renewal shall be for a period not exceeding one year and shall be applied for not less than 15 days prior to the date of expiration of the permit. 
(Code 1975, § 30-3) 
Sec. 70-103. - Permit for single auto trailer. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit to place or maintain a single auto trailer as provided for in section 70-101 shall file with the health commissioner an application within 48 hours after the auto trailer is placed upon the ground of a single-family dwelling, on a form to be furnished by the commissioner. The application shall describe the property where the auto trailer is to be located, either by street and number or by legal description and shall give the date when it is desired to place the auto trailer on the property, the date of expiration of the permit, a statement by the applicant that any toilet in the auto trailer will be sealed so that it cannot be used during the period of its stay on such property, and that all wastewater from sinks and lavatories in the auto trailer will be disposed of in the sewer or in a cesspool if there is no sewer, but not upon the ground in any event. Permits issued under this section shall expire three months after date of issue, and no other such permit shall be issued for the same lot or parcel of land during the nine months following such expiration date. 
(b)  The health commissioner is authorized in the exercise of a reasonable discretion to revoke any permit issued pursuant to this section if, after due investigation, he determines that the holder has violated any of the provisions of this division, or that the auto trailer is being maintained in an unsanitary or unsafe manner or is a nuisance. Written notice of revocation shall be given either by personal delivery to the person to be notified or by giving notice by United States certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to such person at the address which appears on the records of the health commissioner. 
(Code 1975, § 30-4) 
Sec. 70-104. - Application for auto trailer camp permit. 
    Any person desiring a permit for an auto trailer camp shall file an application with the health commissioner on a form to be furnished by him. The application shall give the location by street number and legal description of the property on which the auto trailer camp is to be established and maintained, the dimensions of the property, the number of units in the camp, and such other information as the health commissioner may reasonably require. A plot plan in duplicate of the property shall be filed by the applicant with his application drawn to a scale of not less than one-eighth inch per foot, showing the location and dimensions of all the units, roads, buildings, sewer connections, water connections, electric outlets, baths, toilets and other essential requirements of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 30-5) 
Sec. 70-105. - Limitations of permits. 
(a)  Where no work is done under a permit within 90 days of its issuance under this subdivision, it shall become null and void. 
(b)  Permits issued under the terms of this subdivision convey no right to erect any building other than auto trailers or to do any plumbing or electrical work. Regular building, plumbing, electrical or other permits as required by the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city shall be secured for all such work. 
(Code 1975, § 30-6) 
Sec. 70-106. - Fees. 
(a)  Each application for a permit to establish an auto trailer camp shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of $5.50 for each trailer unit in the camp. Each application for the annual renewal of such permit shall be accompanied by a fee of $5.00 for each trailer unit in the camp. 
(b)  Each application for a permit for a single auto trailer as provided for in section 70-101 shall be accompanied by a fee of $1.00. 
(c)  The health commissioner shall cause an accurate account to be kept of all fees collected under the terms of this subdivision, which account shall show the date of collection, by whom paid, the address for which such payment is made and the amount of each such fee. He shall cause all fees collected under this subdivision to be, from time to time, transferred to the city treasurer. 
(Code 1975, § 30-8) 
Sec. 70-107. - Reinspections. 
    Before issuing a renewal of any permit as provided for in section 70-106(a), the health commissioner shall make a reinspection of the buildings, structures, electrical equipment and plumbing of any auto trailer camp; and no such renewal shall be issued by him unless any defects or violations of law found in the camp have been corrected. 
(Code 1975, § 30-9) 
Sec. 70-108. - Permit revocation. 
(a)  Permits other than those issued pursuant to section 70-103 may be revoked by the health commissioner for violation of the provisions of this division or if the auto trailer camp is maintained in an unsanitary or unsafe manner or in a manner such as to create a nuisance. 
(b)  No such permit shall be revoked until a hearing upon notice by the health commissioner is first had. Written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given at least five days before the hearing. Such notice may be given either by personal delivery to the person to be notified, or by United States certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to such person to be notified at the address which appears on the record pertaining to the matter to which the notice is directed. Such notice shall state in clear and concise language the reasons for revocation of the permit and the time when and the place where the hearing is to be held. The health commissioner may continue the hearings from time to time upon good cause being shown. 
(Code 1975, § 30-7) 
Chapter 74 - NATURAL RESOURCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 82; planning, ch. 90; solid waste, ch. 98; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 102; subdivision regulations, ch. 106; utilities, ch. 118; zoning, app. B. 
State Law reference- Natural resources, W. Va. Code § 20-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMERCIAL WATER WELLS 

Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial well means any well or water source used to obtain water for air conditioning, refrigerating, laundering, washing or other business or industrial purpose. It shall not include wells used exclusively for private homes, for watering stock, or for farm or agricultural purposes. 
(Code 1975, § 32-21) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-32. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 32-33) 
Sec. 74-33. - Permits for commercial wells. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or maintain or cause to be installed or maintained a commercial well unless a permit for such installation or maintenance or both shall have been duly issued by the city engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 32-26) 
Sec. 74-34. - Plans and specifications. 
    No permit for the installation or maintenance of a commercial well shall be issued unless plans and specifications for such well and the surrounding foundations have been submitted to the city engineer and the location, depth and method of installation shall have been duly approved by him. 
(Code 1975, § 32-27) 
Sec. 74-35. - Piping, fitting and connections. 
    All piping, fitting and connections for the conveyance and disposal of water from commercial wells shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the plumbing code. 
(Code 1975, § 32-28) 
Sec. 74-36. - Abandoned wells. 
    Whenever any commercial well is abandoned or no longer used, it shall be solidly filled with compact material. 
(Code 1975, § 32-29) 
Sec. 74-37. - Sewer service charges. 
    The owner of any premises from which water is discharged from commercial wells into city sewers shall meter the flow of such well water and pay sewer service charges to the city on the basis of such measured use, or in the alternative, shall pay such charges on the basis of the quantity of well water flow as estimated by the proper city officer. 
(Code 1975, § 32-30) 
Sec. 74-38. - Deposits in sewers from commercial wells. 
    Wherever, in the case of commercial wells installed before the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, the water taken from such wells is discharged into public sewers, the owner of the premises on which or for which such well is maintained shall pay to the city any expense incurred by it for the removal of sand, gravel or other material deposited in city sewers from any such well. 
(Code 1975, § 32-31) 
Sec. 74-39. - Disposal of water from commercial wells. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person installing a commercial well to permit the water taken from such well to be discharged into the public sewers. Such water shall be disposed of by means of return wells into the earth or by other means approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 32-32) 
Chapter 78 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Courts, ch. 38; traffic ordinance, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- Police power, W. Va. Code § 8-12-5(13), (23), (44). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Attempts; aiding and abetting; procuring offense. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to commit any act which is prohibited by this Code or other ordinance or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority of this Code or such ordinance; and it shall be unlawful for any person to aid or abet another in the commission or attempted commission of any act which is prohibited by this Code or other ordinance or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority of this Code or such ordinance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to avoid the doing of any act which is required by this Code or other ordinance or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority of such ordinance; and it shall be unlawful for any person to aid or abet another in the avoidance or attempted avoidance of any act which is required by this Code or other ordinance or by any rule, regulation, order or notice duly promulgated or given pursuant to authority of this Code or such ordinance. 
(c)  Any person who aids, abets or procures another to commit an offense may be prosecuted and punished as if he were the principal offender. 
(Code 1975, § 18-5) 
State Law reference- Attempts, W. Va. Code § 61-11-8; principals and accessories, W. Va. Code §§ 61-11-6, 61-11-7. 
Sec. 78-2. - Assault and battery definitions; penalties. 
(a)  Assault means an act which places another person in reasonable apprehension of immediately receiving a violent injury. Any person convicted of assault shall be fined not more than $100.00 or confined in jail not more than 30 days, or both. 
(b)  Battery means an unlawful and intentional physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with the person of another, or the unlawful and intentional causing of physical harm to another person. Any person convicted of battery shall be fined not more than $500.00 or confined in jail not more than 30 days, or both. 
(Code 1975, § 18-4) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Assault and battery, W. Va. Code § 61-2-9; authorized penalty for ordinance violations, W. Va. Code §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-5(57), 8-34-1. 
Sec. 78-3. - Advertisements, handbills, signs. 
(a)  No person shall stick, print, stamp, attach, hang or suspend upon any public building, traffic sign or street marker; or upon any pole or upon any telephone, telegraph or other poles belonging to the city or to electric, telephone, telegraph or other companies; or upon any street or sidewalk, pavement or any other public place any printed, written, painted or other advertisement, bill, notice, political poster or advertisement, or any other sign or poster. 
(b)  No papers, handbills, cards, circulars, political advertisements or advertising matter of any kind shall be thrown, pushed, cast, deposited, dropped, scattered or left in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place, or upon any vacant lot or premises within the city, if it is likely that the material might be scattered by the wind upon the streets or public places within the city. The provisions of this section shall not prevent the delivering of newspapers within the city. 
(c)  No structure of any kind to be used as a sign or advertising of any sort shall be built, placed, erected, hung, or left in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place except such as may lawfully be allowed under the laws of the city. 
(d)  Any business or commercial establishment, or any individual or organization whose handbills, signs and advertisements are in violation of this section shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to penalty for such violation. 
(e)  The director of parks and recreation or his authorized agents are directed to remove any signs found within the corporate limits of the city posted in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 18-1.1; Ord. No. 6521, 10-5-1998) 
Sec. 78-4. - Canes and walking sticks. 
    No person who is not totally or partially blind or otherwise incapacitated shall carry on any public street in a raised or extended position a cane or walking stick which is metallic or white in color or white tipped with red. 
(Code 1975, § 18-8) 
Sec. 78-5. - Peeping toms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon any lot or premises without the express or implied consent of the owner, occupant or person in charge of the lot or premises for the purpose of looking into any window, door or other aperture of any dwelling located on the lot or premises. 
(Code 1975, § 18-51) 
Sec. 78-6. - Spitting. 
    No person shall expectorate or spit in or upon any parking lot, footpath or sidewalk in the city, or in or upon any part of any public vehicle carrying passengers for hire, or in or upon any part of any public building under the control of the city, county or state, or of the board of education. The proprietors of public vehicles carrying passengers for hire shall keep posted conspicuously in each of their cars and public vehicles notices forbidding such expectorating or spitting. 
(Code 1975, § 18-62) 
Sec. 78-7. - Throwing missiles in streets or public places. 
    No person within the city shall throw any stone, brick, stick, can or other missile in or into any street or highway, open space, public square or enclosure. 
(Code 1975, § 18-63) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 102. 
Sec. 78-8. - Ticket scalping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resell or offer for resale within the city any ticket, token or other evidence of the right of admission or entry to any place of amusement where public exhibitions, games, contests or performances of any kind are given, held or conducted, or are to be given, held or conducted, which place is owned by the city, or any other municipal, county or state body or agency, at a price in excess of the price printed or otherwise appearing on the face of such ticket, token or other evidence of the right of admission or entry. Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the general penalties as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1975, § 18-63.1) 
Sec. 78-9. - Watercraft regulations. 
(a)  Tying to bridge. No person shall anchor, hitch, tie or otherwise fasten any steamboat, barge, raft, other craft or timbers or materials of any kind or description to any bridge, bridge pier, abutment or any approach to any such bridge owned or controlled in whole or in part by the city. 
(b)  Muffling watercraft. The operation of watercraft in violation of section 78-212 on the Kanawha and Elk rivers within the confines of the city is prohibited. 
(c)  Mooring at city levee. No commercially owned steamboat, barge, raft, boat or any other craft of any kind or description shall be moored, anchored, hitched, tied or otherwise fastened to any part of the city-owned levee without prior written approval of the city manager. No privately owned boat, steamboat, barge, raft or any other craft of any kind or description shall be moored, anchored, hitched, tied or otherwise fastened to any part of the city-owned levee for longer than two hours without prior written approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 18-65; Bill No. 7375, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 78-10. - Hate crimes. 
(a)  This section may be referred to as the "Anti-Hate Crime Ordinance." The city hereby recognizes and declares that all persons within the city have the right to be free from any violence, or intimidation by threat of violence, committed against their person or property because of their actual or perceived race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, political affiliation, physical or mental disability, sex or sexual orientation. For the purposes of this section, "sexual orientation" shall have the definition set forth in section 62-3 of this Code. 
(b)  The State of West Virginia has enacted legislation (found at W. Va. Code § 61-6-21(1987)) deeming certain hate crimes felonious conduct. The purpose of this article is to expand and create additional classifications against which hate crimes will not be tolerated within the city as set forth in subsections (c), (d), (e), (f) and (g) hereof. 
(c)  If any person does by force or threat of force willfully injure, oppress, threaten, intimidate or interfere with, or attempt to injure, oppress, threaten, intimidate or interfere with any other person in the free exercise or enjoyment of any right or privilege secured to him or her by the ordinances of the city, the Constitution or laws of the State of West Virginia or by the Constitution or laws of the United States, because of such other person's actual or perceived race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, political affiliation, physical or mental disability, or sexual orientation, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be jailed not more than 30 days and fined not more than $500.00. 
(d)  If any person conspires with another person to willfully injure, oppress, threaten, intimidate or interfere with any other person in the free exercise or enjoyment of any right or privilege secured to him or her by the ordinances of the city, the constitution or laws of the State of West Virginia or by the Constitution or laws of the United States, because of such other person's actual or perceived race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, political affiliation, physical or mental disability or sexual orientation and in willful furtherance thereof to assemble with one or more persons for the purpose of teaching any technique or means capable of causing property damage, bodily injury or death which such persons or person intend to employ to violate this section each such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be jailed not more than 30 days and fined not more than $500.00. 
(e)  The fact that a person committed a felony or misdemeanor, or attempted to commit a felony or misdemeanor, because of the victim's actual or perceived race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, political affiliation, physical or mental disability or sexual orientation shall be considered a circumstance in aggravation of any crime in imposing sentence. 
(f)  Nothing contained in this section makes unlawful the teaching of any technique in self-defense. 
(g)  In any prosecution under this section, (i) evidence proving the defendant's mere abstract beliefs or (ii) evidence of the defendant's mere membership in an organization, shall not be admissible to establish any element of an offense under this section, unless such evidence bears a direct relationship to the underlying crime. Thus, this subsection will not bar all evidence of membership or belief, but would assure that at a minimum, any speech or association that is not contemporaneous with the crime must be part of the chain of events that led to the crime. 
(h)  If any part of this section is deemed unconstitutional or unenforceable, the remaining provisions will remain in effect. 
(Bill No. 6863, § 18-4.1, 2-4-2002; Bill No. 7427, 7-19-2010) 
Secs. 78-11-78-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY RIGHTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against property rights, W. Va. Code § 61-3-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-41. - Rewards authorized in certain cases. 
(a)  The city is authorized to pay a reward of $50.00 to anyone, except law enforcement officers employed by the city, giving information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person, adult or minor, tampering with or destroying any parking meter of the city, and a reward of $25.00 to anyone, except law enforcement officers employed by the city, giving information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person, adult or minor, tampering with or destroying any street sign of the city. 
(b)  These rewards will be paid by the city treasurer upon receipt of authorization from the mayor. 
(Code 1975, § 18-55) 
Sec. 78-42. - Libraries and related offenses. 
(a)  Unauthorized taking of books, materials. No person shall take from any public library any book, pamphlet, periodical, paper or other property except in accordance with the rules of such library. 
(b)  Failure to return materials after notice. No person shall willfully retain any book, pamphlet, periodical, paper or other property belonging to any public library for 30 days after the date of mailing a notice to his address that, under the rules, the time for retaining the book, pamphlet, paper or other property has expired. 
(c)  Destroying or injuring materials. No person shall willfully or wantonly cut, mutilate, mark, tear, write upon, deface or otherwise destroy or injure, in whole or in part, any book, pamphlet, periodical, map, document, written, engraved or printed paper belonging to any public library, or shall suffer such injury to be inflicted while such property is in his custody, or shall willfully or wantonly injure any of the furniture or property belonging to any public library. 
(Code 1975, § 18-43) 
State Law reference- Larceny, W. Va. Code § 61-1-13; willful retention of library materials, W. Va. Code § 10-1-11; property damage, W. Va. Code § 61-3-30. 
Sec. 78-43. - Befouling property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to befoul or disturb public property or the property of another so as to create a hazardous, unhealthy or physically offensive condition. 
(Code 1975, § 18-6) 
Secs. 78-44-78-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY DAMAGE AND RELATED OFFENSES[3] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 78-61. - Tampering with city property generally. 
(a)  No person shall, without proper authority, knowingly use, tamper with, render inoperative, conceal, destroy, damage, remove, deface, molest or otherwise interfere with any books, records, furniture, equipment, gear, apparatus, tools or other items of personal property belonging to, leased to or used by the city or any agency of the city. 
(b)  No person shall, without proper authority, knowingly destroy, damage, deface, molest or otherwise interfere with or trespass upon any real property belonging to, leased to or used by the city or any agency of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-14)

(a)  No person shall, knowingly and without proper authority, use, tamper with, render inoperative, conceal, destroy, damage, remove, deface, molest or otherwise interfere with any personal property of another. 
(b)  No person shall, knowingly and without proper authority, destroy, damage, deface, molest or otherwise interfere with or trespass upon any real property of another. 
(Code 1975, § 18-52)

DIVISION 3. - LARCENY AND RELATED OFFENSES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Larceny and related offenses, W. Va. Code § 61-3-13 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 78-81. - Petit larceny. 
    No person within the city shall commit simple, petit larceny of money, goods or chattels. 
(Code 1975, § 18-40) 
State Law reference- Larceny, W. Va. Code § 61-3-13. 
Sec. 78-82. - Embezzlement and larceny. 
(a)  No person shall embezzle, steal, hide, purloin or carry away any money, property or writing which is the property of the city. 
(b)  No person shall receive, steal or aid in stealing, or have in possession with intent to convert to his own use any money, property or writing which is the property of the city, knowing it to have been embezzled, stolen or purloined from the city by any other person. 
(Code 1975, § 18-15) 
Sec. 78-83. - Receiving stolen property. 
    No person shall buy or receive from another person, or aid in concealing, or transfer to a person other than the owner any stolen goods or other thing of value which he knows or has reason to believe has been stolen. 
(Code 1975, § 18-41) 
State Law reference- Receiving or transferring stolen goods, W. Va. Code § 61-3-18. 
Sec. 78-84. - Larceny by trick. 
    No person shall obtain possession of or title to anything of value, with the consent of the person from whom he obtained it, if he induced such consent by a false or fraudulent representation, pretense, token or writing. Whoever violates this section is guilty of larceny by trick. 
(Code 1975, § 18-42) 
State Law reference- Obtaining property by false pretenses, W. Va. Code § 61-3-24. 
Sec. 78-85. - Meters measuring, companies furnishing utilities. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Gas, water or electric corporation or gas, water or electric company includes every corporation, company, association, joint stock association, partnership and person, their lessees, trustees or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, operating, managing or controlling any plant or property for manufacturing, supplying, producing, distributing and selling illuminating or natural gas, water or electricity for light, heat or power, within the corporate limits of this city. 
(b)  Meters; certificates of readings. It shall be the duty of any gas, water or electric company or person supplying gas, water or electricity to the citizens of the city to give to the consumer supplied, when requested by such consumer to do so, a written certificate of the reading of any such meter so installed when the meter shall be first put into service; and it shall furnish such consumer, when requested by such consumer to do so, with a certificate containing a copy of the reading of such meter whenever it is read by the corporation or its agents. Also, whether so requested or not, the company shall furnish the consumer a certificate of the reading of such meter whenever it shall be removed from the premises for any purpose. Such certificate shall be in writing or upon printed forms, the figures to be put down in ink or indelible pencil, and shall be signed by the person who reads the meter. This certificate may be left with the consumer or with any employee of the consumer over the age of 16 years, or any member of his family over the age of 16 years if no other person should be found upon the premises. This certificate shall contain the name of the consumer, the location of the meter, as well as the reading and date of reading of such meter. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this subsection, or to furnish a false certificate or reading, or to change or alter any such certificate or reading, upon any certificate or card so furnished by the inspector or company's agent. 
(c)  Injury to or interference with meter. It shall be unlawful for any person, whether engaged in the business of selling or supplying artificial or natural gas, water or electric current or power, or whether a consumer, or any other person, willfully to injure, deface, break, stop up, open, unseal or otherwise tamper with any meter which has been placed in commission, or in anywise to adjust or interfere with such meter so as to prevent the proper and accurate measurements of the gas, electric current or water passing through such meter. 
(Code 1975, § 18-45) 
State Law reference- Procuring utility service by device with intent to defraud, W. Va. Code § 61-3-44; injury to utility property, W. Va. Code § 61-3-29. 
Secs. 78-86-78-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Shoplifting[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Shoplifting, W. Va. Code § 61-3A-1 et seq. 

Sec. 78-101. - Prohibited; definitions. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of shoplifting if, with intent to appropriate merchandise without paying the merchant's stated price for the merchandise, such person, alone or in concert with another person, knowingly: 
(1)  Conceals the merchandise upon his person or in another manner; 
(2)  Removes or causes the removal of merchandise from the mercantile establishment or beyond the last station for payment; 
(3)  Alters, transfers or removes any price marking affixed to the merchandise; 
(4)  Transfers the merchandise from one container to another; 
(5)  Causes the cash register or other sales recording device to reflect less than the merchant's stated price for the merchandise; or 
(6)  Removes a shopping cart from the premises of the mercantile establishment. 
(b)  A person also commits the offense of shoplifting if such person, alone or in concert with another person, knowingly and with intent obtains an exchange or refund or attempts to obtain an exchange or refund for merchandise which has not been purchased from the mercantile establishment. 
(c)  Evidence of stated price or ownership of merchandise may include but is not limited to: 
(1)  The actual merchandise alleged to have been shoplifted; 
(2)  The unaltered content of the price tag or marking from such merchandise; or 
(3)  Properly identified photographs of such merchandise. 
(d)  Any merchant may testify at a trial as to the stated price or ownership of merchandise, as well as to other matters pertaining to the case. 
(e)  Upon a first shoplifting conviction: 
(1)  When the value of the merchandise is less than or equal to $500.00, the defendant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $250.00. 
(2)  When the value of the merchandise exceeds $500.00, the defendant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, which fine shall not be suspended, or the defendant shall be imprisoned in the county jail not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(f)  Upon a second shoplifting conviction: 
(1)  When the value of the merchandise is less than or equal to $500.00, the defendant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, which fines shall not be suspended, or the defendant shall be imprisoned in the county jail not more than one month, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(2)  When the value of the merchandise exceeds $500.00, the defendant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than $500.00 and shall be imprisoned in the county jail for not less than one month. 
(g)  In addition to the fines and imprisonment imposed by this section, in all cases of conviction for the offense of shoplifting, the court shall order the defendant to pay a penalty to the mercantile establishment involved in the amount of $50.00 or double the value of the merchandise involved, whichever is higher, unless the mercantile establishment agrees to a waiver or reduction of such penalty, and the municipal court judge approves said waiver or reduction. The mercantile establishment shall be entitled to collect such mandatory penalty as in the case of a civil judgment. This penalty shall be in addition to the mercantile establishment's rights to recover the stolen merchandise. 
(h)  In determining the number of prior shoplifting convictions for purposes of imposing punishment under this section, the court shall disregard all such convictions occurring more than seven years prior to the shoplifting offense in question. 
(i)  An act of shoplifting is declared to constitute a breach of peace; and any owner of merchandise, his agent or employee, or any law enforcement officer who has reasonable ground to believe that a person has committed shoplifting may detain such person in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time not to exceed 30 minutes, for the purpose of investigating whether or not such person has committed or attempted to commit shoplifting. Such reasonable detention shall not constitute an arrest, nor shall it render the owner of merchandise, his agent or employee, liable to the person detained. 
(j)  Conceal means to hide, hold or carry merchandise so that, although there may be some notice of its presence, it is not visible through ordinary observation. 
(k)  Merchant means an owner or operator of any mercantile establishment and includes the merchant's employee's servants, security agent or other agents. 
(l)  Mercantile establishment means any place where merchandise is displayed, held or offered for sale, either at retail or wholesale. The term does not include adjoining parking lots or adjoining areas of common use with other establishments. 
(m)  Merchandise means any goods, foodstuffs, wares or personal property, or any part or portion, of any type or description displayed, held or offered for sale, or a shopping cart. 
(n)  Value of merchandise means the merchant's stated price of the merchandise or, in the event of altering, transferring or removing a price marking or causing a cash register or other sales device to reflect a less than the retail value of the merchandise, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, the difference between the merchant's stated price of the merchandise and the altered price. 
(Code 1975, § 18-58; Ord. No. 6669, 5-15-2000; Bill. No. 7372, 1-20-2009) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-102. - Constitutes breach of peace; detention of suspects. 
    An act of shoplifting as defined in section 78-101 is declared to constitute a breach of peace; and any owner of merchandise, his agent or employee, or any city police officer who has reasonable ground to believe that a person has committed shoplifting may detain such person in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time not to exceed 30 minutes for the purpose of investigating whether or not such person has committed or attempted to commit shoplifting. Such reasonable detention shall not constitute an arrest nor shall it render the owner of merchandise, his agent or employee, liable to the person detained. 
(Code 1975, § 18-60) 
Secs. 78-103-78-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC SAFETY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-131. - False alarms and reports. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly give or cause to be given any false alarm of fire. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly give or cause to be given any false alarm of explosion or impending danger of explosion. 
(c)  No person shall knowingly give or cause to be given any false alarm of the need for police protection, assistance or investigation, or any false report to the police department. 
(d)  No person shall knowingly give or cause to be given any false alarm of the need for an ambulance or medical assistance. 
(e)  No person shall knowingly give or cause to be given to the emergency services department, or to representatives of the press, radio or television, any false report of catastrophe or impending catastrophe. 
(Code 1975, § 18-23) 
State Law reference- False bomb reports, W. Va. Code § 61-6-17; falsely reporting an emergency incident, W. Va. Code § 61-6-20. 
Sec. 78-132. - Aircraft regulations. 
(a)  Minimum altitude. No person shall operate an aircraft at an altitude of less than 1,000 feet over this city, except at a duly established airport or when necessary to make a safe and proper landing or take off in an emergency or at a duly established airport. 
(b)  Reckless flying. No person shall operate an aircraft in the air over, or on the ground or water within this city in a careless and reckless manner in willful or wanton disregard of the rights or safety of others, or without due caution and circumspection and in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. 
(c)  Stunt flying. All stunt flying within the corporate limits of the city is prohibited. 
(d)  Releasing handbills, other printed materials. No handbills or other printed matter or announcements shall be released from or distributed by any aircraft over or within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-2) 
State Law reference- Aeronautics, W. Va. Code § 29-2A-1 et seq.; reckless operation of aircraft, W. Va. Code § 29-2A-12. 
Sec. 78-133. - Airtight containers. 
    No person shall abandon, discard or knowingly permit to remain on premises under his control, in a place accessible to children, any refrigerator or other airtight or semiairtight container which has a capacity of 11/2 cubic feet or more and an opening of 50 square inches or more and which has a door or lid equipped with hinge, latch or other fastening device capable of securing such door or lid without rendering such equipment harmless to human life by removing such hinges, latches or other hardware which may cause a person to be confined. This section shall not apply to an icebox, refrigerator or other airtight or semiairtight container located in that part of a building occupied by a dealer, warehouseman or repairman. 
(Code 1975, § 18-3) 
State Law reference- Abandoning iceboxes, W. Va. Code § 61-2-26. 
Sec. 78-134. - Skylights and fire escapes. 
    Skylights and fire escapes on every building shall be kept free from accumulations of ice and snow or materials of any kind by the person in control or charge of the building. 
(Code 1975, § 18-61) 
Secs. 78-135-78-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEAPONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Local restrictions on firearms and weapons, W. Va. Code §§ 8-12-5(16), 8-12-5a.
